TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. As the Government's assets test panel is now considering an after death confiscation of assets as a pre-condition to granting certain pensions, is the Prime Minister aware that such a scheme would strike not only at the elderly but also at their children? Is the Prime Minister aware that such a scheme would attack the upward mobility of Australian families, and is the Prime Minister aware that such a scheme would discriminate against the children of income-poor but asset-owning parents?

—I appreciate the question from the Leader of the Opposition. I simply want to say two things: The Government, of course, has not yet received the report of the Gruen Committee, if I can so describe it. Therefore, it would be premature to make any observations upon any hypothetical proposition. Having said that, I say to the Leader of the Opposition that I am aware that the sort of proposal to which he refers would cause some concerns of that type.
—Can the Prime Minister advise the House whether the remarkable improvement in the Australian economy so far this financial year can be continued next financial year and beyond?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Banks for his very penetrating question. Without a doubt, the Government is very successfully laying the basis for long term economic recovery. What is crystal clear is that our balanced fiscal policy and our workable wages policy, based on the prices and incomes accord, will be particularly important in ensuring that long term economic recovery.

ANSWER.PARA: The economic turn-around which has so far been achieved is remarkable by any standards. Growth through the year will be of the order of at least 10 per cent, the highest of any Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. That, of course, reflects in part the very successful economic policies of this Government and also, as is just as clear, it reflects some particular factors like the breaking of the drought.

It also reflects the severity of the recession which was inflicted upon this country by our predecessors. In large measure we have achieved the remarkable results this year simply by straightening out the economic mess which we inherited. Next year, we will be consolidating and building upon the gains that we have already made.

Having referred to those remarkable results, it is quite clear that no one could expect that during the next financial year or beyond we will continue with those quite stunning rates in economic growth that were achieved in 1983-84. Having said that, it is also equally clear that next financial year we will see growth at very solid levels and at a level which will enable us to continue to wind back the level of unemployment.

There will be a minimal wage rise in about October of this year. Very importantly, that minimal wage rise at the end of this year will help us to continue to reduce inflation in this country. It should be remembered that, even excluding the effects of Medicare, we have already got inflation down to the lowest level in a decade. In other words, we have done more in one year than the previous Government did in seven years with its so-called fight-inflation-first policy.

We are restoring Australia's economic health, and the Australian people can be absolutely assured that the dark days of double-digit inflation, economic contraction and growing unemployment-there was a rise of a quarter of a million unemployed in the previous Government's last year in office-are behind them.

Mr Speaker, the Budget will continue the policy and the process of building Australia's economic growth. It is very important to say that in the next Budget we will produce significant tax cuts. But there will be one thing different from the tax cuts which this Government will produce in its Budget this year. They will not be seized back after the election as they were in 1977 by the previous Government. The people of Australia will recall that in the election of 1975 the present Opposition went to the people and said: 'We will hold on to Medibank and we will hold on to full wage indexation'. It broke those promises. In 1977 honourable members opposite said: 'We will give you tax cuts'. They did and took them back. Honourable members opposite misled people in 1975; they misled them in 1977; and they misled them in 1983.

I conclude by saying that since Federation there has been no political grouping in the history of this country which has had such a low political trust factor with the Australian electorate as the people sitting opposite. The situation developed to the point where the people simply did not trust them. They do not trust them now and they will not trust them in the future when they attempt to misrepresent the successful economic policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, follows in part the previous answer which he gave and which once again he read to the Parliament today. It follows, of course, the earlier question which I asked wherein he conceded that his assets test panel would have, if it brought in the after death confiscation of assets that it is proposing, the following effects: Striking not only at the elderly but also at children; would attack the outward mobility of Australian families; and would discriminate against the children of income poor but asset owning parents. All that was conceded by the Prime Minister. I ask firstly: Will he indicate his disapproval of these effects or is that group of people to suffer the confusion and anxiety that all the elderly have suffered since May of last year as a result of the mini-Budget? Secondly, no matter what the assets test panel recommends, will the Prime Minister give an assurance that under no circumstances will his Government introduce death duties either directly or by stealth of measures such as taxing pensioners' assets after their death?

—If there is any confusion amongst the groups of people to whom the Leader of the Opposition refers it is because of the deliberate campaign which he and those behind him have been deliberately building up in this country. It is a measure of the confidence that the people of this country and their relevant organisations have in this Government and its approach on this matter that we were able to get such a widely representative group of people to serve with Professor Gruen to deal dispassionately, competently and without political interference. It is not the intention of this Government to interfere in this matter. We will wait until we receive the report of the committee; we will consider it and then we will make the decision which we know will be accepted by the overwhelming majority of the people of this country.
—Will the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House of the current situation in regard to the lengthy dispute at the New Parliament House site?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canberra for her question. I am very much aware of her concern about this important industrial dispute in her electorate. I assure her that the Government very much shares her concern over this dispute which has now gone on for almost 14 weeks. About 600 existing jobs have been lost because of the dispute and another 600 jobs which would have been created this year will be delayed and put at risk. The background to this dispute is that the site agreement which ended at the end of last year was up for renegotiation. There were three claims of importance in the renegotiation procedures. They were for an increase in the site allowance, the application of severance pay and a superannuation scheme. The Government's view of those claims was that severance pay is simply not on. It is not normally paid, as far as I am aware, in the building industry and is not paid on any government site in Australia. Superannuation was something to be considered in national negotiations which were then foreshadowed and which are still going on. The Government felt that the site allowance was something to be determined by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission within the wage fixing principles.

ANSWER.PARA: The current situation is that the dispute is now centred around the site allowance. Commissioner Brown has heard argument from all parties about the increase that should be given in the site allowance. He reserved his decision on 18 April, almost three weeks ago, and indicated then to the unions that when there was a return to work he would make his decision known. Since then the unions have not seen fit to recommend a return to work, for reasons which are best known to themselves. However, I am pleased to say that, at the instigation of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, they have now finally agreed to hold a meeting on Thursday of this week at 10 o'clock at the Canberra Workers Club. That meeting will involve all Parliament House workers who are members of the three unions which instigated the industrial dispute-the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, the Builders Labourers Federation and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition obviously is not interested in this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dispute has been going on for weeks and all you can do is read your bit of paper.
—The Leader of the Opposition would like us to give in to the claims. Is that his solution? He would like us to give in to all the claims.
—You have done nothing.
—Order!
—Is that how he would solve it? Under his industrial relations policy that is how it would be solved. He would solve it in that way.
—You have no industrial relations policy.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. With respect, your duty is to both sides of the House. Are you warning the Minister as well as me or only me?

—I point out to the Leader of the Opposition that I was on my feet calling for order. I was going to speak to both the Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. The Minister ceased talking and the Leader of the Opposition kept on interjecting. That is why I had to bring him to order.

—As I was saying, it is unfortunate that there is no certainty that the motion that will be put to the meeting on Thursday by the union delegates will recommend a return to work. I say there is no certainty because we simply do not know, but there are some indications that some unions may not be anxious to support a return to work, despite the fact that the ACTU strongly supports that development. The Government is greatly concerned that a decision could be taken to stay out in the hope of an offer being made. I want to say quite clearly and unequivocally that the Government position is that there will be no offer. What we have said is what will be the situation in the future: This matter is to be decided by arbitration, and we stick to that. Nothing will change our view of that.

ANSWER.PARA: However, if despite that being clearly understood by all job delegates they were of a mind to take a decision not to go back to work at this stage, they should do so understanding that the Government would then have to consider all its available options, included amongst which would be complete closure of the Parliament House site and the review of the future program of government and government-related contracts for construction in the ACT. Those are quite drastic and unpalatable options but they are options which the Government will certainly have to consider because we will--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite correct in doing it.

—I am so pleased that the Leader of the Opposition agrees. It will be unavoidable if the unions and their members do not accept the dispute settlement procedures which are now available to them. We call on all members who are entitled to attend that meeting to exercise their right to do so, to support the ACTU, the national interest and their own interests by voting for a return to work so that the arbitrator can announce his decision and we can get the Parliament House site going again.

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister read the editorial in yesterday's Australian Financial Review headed 'Racism and intolerance'? On what basis does the Minister justify his arrogant and intolerant approach to the handling of his portfolio and his persistent tendency to label as racist anybody inside or outside this Parliament who dares to question or criticise his policies and statements? ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

—You are a loud mouthed larrikin, are you not?
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark that he made across the table.
—I withdraw.
—I ask honourable members on my left to allow the Minister to answer. I am unable to hear clearly what he is saying.

—I have never labelled anyone, in this House or outside, a racist for making informed comment on immigration matters. That is not what we have seen in the last few weeks after the Government and I made certain approaches to the Leader of the Opposition and his supporters for at least an informed debate which might produce a bipartisan policy in answer to certain undesirable elements that were intruding into the immigration debate from outside.

—I have made it clear that we are getting moderate increases in Asian people as a result of universally applied family reunion criteria, universally applied independent skilled migration criteria and universally applied business migration criteria. The fact is that we inherited an Indo-Chinese refugee program. The number of approvals has gone down from 15,500 people two years ago to 10,000 this year, and further moderate reductions are proposed. The honourable member for Denison and certain members of the Opposition are saying that certain globally applied formulae inside all of the components of the migration program are producing a few more Asians. I have not allowed the favoured arrangements for the Big Brother Movement Ltd to continue, and that position was supported by the former Minister. The honourable member for Balaclava's policy was reversed by the honourable member for Petrie when he became Minister. This afternoon I intend to table the documents during the debate on the matter of public importance.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. On what basis will the Minister do that? I had to write to the Prime Minister yesterday to ask for those documents and I still have not received them.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr Speaker, it is not that the Prime Minister will not make them available to me; he obviously will and his office has already told me he will. However, the Minister has no right to have them.
—Order! I understand that that is not a matter for Parliament; it is a matter for the conventions of government.

—The former Minister would well know-if he listens I will explain the point-that he was disenchanted with the positive discrimination that was given to the Big Brother Movement and intended to reverse that policy. Before he could do so he was replaced as Minister by the former member for Petrie who reinstated favouritism to the Big Brother Movement. The documents that I have and intend to table are the directions from my Department to my London office. They will prove what former Ministers did. I return to the thread of what I was saying. I am thoroughly discouraged with the attitude of members of the Opposition. The Opposition well knows that we are applying globally non-discriminatory policies. Because those policies are producing a few more Asians it is prepared to jump on the bandwagon.
—You moved. Mick Young developed a bipartisan policy.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition is going beyond the tolerance of the Chair.

—We have given members of the Opposition all the facts about this and they well know that we are not anti-British. They well know that we are not pro- Asian. To conclude, in a spirit of consensus, I challenge them--
—We noted that. He is getting the wind-up. Mick told him to shut up.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting. An amount of tolerance is allowed to the Leader of the Opposition and indeed to the front bench on the Opposition side, but not to the degree where a Minister cannot answer a question because of the constant exchange across the table. I will have no alternative but to act if it continues. The Minister will conclude his answer.

—If members of the Opposition want to persist in saying that our policies are quite coldly and deliberately anti-British and pro-Asian, I want them to tell us where they would make the cuts. Where would they impose the quotas? They can tell me just what they would do. Would they impose quotas in regard to Asians coming here under the family reunion program? Would they cut the refugee program? Would they cut the business migration program? Would the Opposition reduce the family reunion program from 40,000 to the 25,000 that it introduced simply because we are getting too many Asians in that program under globally applied policies? The Opposition has no answer to what I am saying.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude on this note: If the Opposition persists in making these charges I want to know where it would make the cuts. Would it terminate the refugee program altogether and thus antagonise our Association of South East Asian Nations partners? Would it cut the family reunion program simply because we are getting too many Asians? Would it impose quotas? I ask the Opposition to tell me what it would do. Why does it not cut out the nonsensical remarks? If we are to have a debate upon immigration, let it be an informed debate and let us aim at some consensus and bipartisanship in refugee and family reunion policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence aware of the concentrated efforts being made, particularly by the Bannon Labor Government, to present the advantages of South Australia as a possible site for the construction of the new submarines required by the Royal Australian Navy? In light of reports today about a West German interest in the construction of those submarines, could the Minister advise the House on the current situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The submarine project is probably generating more activity within Australia and outside than most programs announced by governments. All six State governments are now involved in programs to secure for their areas the construction of the submarines. Certainly all of the members of this Parliament and the Government of South Australia have been promoting their claims to this project over a considerable period.

ANSWER.PARA: Since I have been Minister, I have met with representatives of either the governments or those seeking to be chosen as the prime contractors from all of the areas which are involved. There are six proposals for a design which are currently subject to a definition study. That design evaluation is expected to be narrowed to two company proposals which will then be subject to further studies for the choice of a design of a submarine for the Royal Australian Navy.

I did have some discussions with Dr Westphal, as I have had with a number of others. The Government is not in a position at this stage to indicate either in which State the submarine is likely to be constructed or which design is likely to be chosen for further progressing to the ultimate choice. The design will be finalised in 1986 and contracts should be proposed in 1987.

I would anticipate that, in the second definition stage, which will involve the assessment of Australian content, the degree of Australian construction and the proposed location, the present intense competition, especially among the various States of Australia, for the construction program will increase. At this stage it is not possible to give any more precise indication of that.

My Department and the Department of Defence Support are engaged in evaluations and when those evaluations are completed an announcement will be made. I thank the honourable member and other honourable members of this Parliament for their support and enthusiasm for this program.

ANSWER.PARA: What we are getting from the Northern Territory Administration, as we move to solve problems which we have inherited by the lack of action on the part of the previous Federal Government and the Chief Minister's Government, is the same kind of political double talk that takes place in this Parliament. The fact of the matter is that Mr Everingham knows he is conning the people of the Northern Territory. He can no longer con the miners. He certainly cannot con the Aborigines but I have no doubt he will continue to con some of the honourable gentlemen opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consider that the 12,500 young people brought from Britain to Australia under the Big Brother Movement for nearly six decades have made a valuable and worthwhile contribution to this nation? Does the Minister believe that the late Ben Chifley was misguided in agreeing to serve for many years as a member of the Board of the Big Brother Movement? Does he believe that Prime Minister Whitlam and the Minister for Immigration, Mr Grassby, were wrong in giving the Big Brother Movement their full and total support in the years 1972 to 1975?

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member is seeking merely an expression of opinion as to the Minister's view. It is not a matter for which the Minister is administratively responsible. The question is out of order.

—In the initial stage, the honourable member asked a direct question. I believe, with regard to the personalities involved, that he is out of order on those points because they are matters of opinion.
—Finally, I ask: Where does the Minister claim a mandate to terminate the outstanding and beneficial activities of the Big Brother Movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not want to say in any way that I would dispute decisions taken by any of my illustrious colleague predecessors. I simply make the point, and honourable members opposite should consider it well, that the halcyon days of virtually unlimited immigration, when we took tens of thousands of independent migrants, are virtually over. Only 70,000 people will come to Australia this year. Most of them will come under the family reunion scheme or as refugees. I ask honourable members to consider how British people who might be rejected and do not get through the family reunion assessment system would feel when, say, up to 200 people are accepted by the Big Brother Movement, an organisation which is outside government, and they get through under the criteria determined by this organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision regarding the Big Brother Movement was a government decision. It was certainly agreed to by one of the former Government's Ministers. That Minister said that perhaps the Big Brother Movement discriminated against the sexes because there was no mention of the little sisters. In 60 years only one female was ever brought into Australia by the Big Brother Movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister use his very high standing in this Parliament and the community and ask the Leader of the Opposition and some of the more rational honourable members opposite to behave in a responsible fashion on the question of immigration, remembering that Australia will still be situated in this geographical area well after the next election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hope that all members in this House would understand the seriousness of the question and the very important considerations that are involved in it. I assure you, Mr Speaker, that in answering this question I will not make any partisan political points. I hope that in listening to the answer the Leader of the Opposition will accept the spirit in which I make the observations that I do. Mr Speaker, it is legitimate in politics that serious issues of difference of principle between parties should be vigorously aired. I would have thought that one of the redeeming features of the Australian political scene over many years and up until very recent days has been the distinctly observable and identifiable bipartisanship which has existed in this country on the question of immigration. I refer not only to the question of immigration generally but perhaps most particularly to the question of immigration from Asian countries. It has been the fact that we can say quite accurately that there has been this bipartisanship on the matter generally that I have referred to and on the particular matter.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been to me, to people on this side of the House and, I thought, on the other side, a matter of pride that in respect of the obligation of this country following, particularly, the conflict in Indo-China-I do not want to go back to the causes and responsibilities in that matter-decisions were taken by the previous Government that Australia had a moral obligation with respect to the situation in which we had been involved there. I repeat: I make no observations about responsibility in that matter because I want this to be a bipartisan issue . But there was across the political spectrum in this country an acceptance of the obligation upon Australia to take into Australia refugees who resulted from that conflict and when our predecessor Government adopted that policy, we in opposition, without equivocation supported that policy. In the event, we know that some emotions were aroused and still exist in this country because of the decision of the previous Government, supported by the then Opposition, that we had a moral obligation to bring in under our immigration program the refugee component from the Asian area. The previous Government did that; we lauded it and we supported it. What this Government has done is to continue those policies .

I believe in respect of this matter that the Leader of the Opposition shares the views that we have. In that respect, my attention has just been drawn-I do him credit by referring to this-to a passage from the Courier-Mail of 22 March this year under the heading 'Migrant level no problem: Peacock'. I will refer to what I regard as the relevant passages of the article and obviously the Leader of the Opposition can see the whole of it. However, I go to those parts which I think are relevant to what I have to say. The article states:
The Federal Opposition Leader, Mr Peacock, yesterday in effect supported the Federal Government's Asian immigration program.
He said provided the Government did not substantially increase the ratio of Asian immigrants to Australia, he did not expect the issue to be 'inflammatory'.
The article continued:

Mr Peacock also said that Professor Geoffrey Blainey had done the Australian community a service by raising the issue, but had gone a 'little too far' with his description of the 'Asianisation of Australia'.
The article went on to say:
Mr Peacock said Australia had a 'profound duty' to be sympathetic to the plight of refugees.

I applaud the Leader of the Opposition for those remarks as reported. I put this plea to the Leader of the Opposition, and to those behind him who I think share that responsible view: I believe it is in the interests of this country and in the interests of our relations with the countries of this area that we do not sink into the situation where, on either side, we try to score cheap political points on an issue which all of us know constitutes a very grave risk of rousing uninformed emotions, bias and prejudice in this country which raise the possibility of injury and damage to citizens of this country and of damage to the relations with other countries in this area. I say straightforwardly to the Leader of the Opposition that I seek no political advantage in what I am saying. I believe that we are entering into very dangerous waters if there is any attempt to seek political advantage out of this emotional human issue. I say to this House and to the people of this country that this Government will continue, without discrimination, the policies that were instituted by the previous Government.

I repeat that I applaud the previous Government for those policies. I believe they were correct and humane. This Government is continuing them without fear or favour. I hope that the Leader of the Opposition and those around him will join with me and with those on this side of the House in saying once and for all that we will not allow to become a political issue in this country the question of Asianisation or the question of immigrants coming into this country from one area or another. We will not introduce discriminatory quotas. The previous Government refused to do that and it was right. We will not do it either. We do not seek to inflame base emotions in this country. It will be to the great service of this country and all its citizens, and to our relations with countries in this area, if we cease to allow, by anything that we on either side of this House say or do, this very dangerous issue to be raised and to become something that is in the forefront of political debate. Honourable members on both sides of the House have a duty and a responsibility, not immediately to the people that we represent but to all the people of Australia and to the countries of this region, to bring an end once and for all to the misleading suggestion that there is some preference for Asians, some Asianisation. That is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not say that.

—I am not saying that the Leader of the Opposition said it. These suggestions are being made. I do not want to throw the blame at any person. I make a plea to the Leader of the Opposition and those around him to join with me in giving an undertaking to the people of Australia and the countries of this region that we will not allow this emotional issue to raise its head any further in this country as a result of anything that anyone on either side of this House says. I ask that further questions be--
—Give me the opportunity to ask about that. I want to ask about that.
—What is the Leader of the Opposition seeking to do?
—I wish to ask the Prime Minister a question.

—I had intended to ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. I understood that the Leader of the Opposition indicated he would like to ask me a question related to what I said and, of course, I ask that he be allowed to do so.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and I preface it by saying that all members on this side of the House endorse the ideals that he has stated. Nobody on this side of the House with tacit or avowed support would engage in racist propaganda. Indeed, my length of service in the field of international relations and all the work that I did in this area in conjunction with Ministers for immigration and ethnic affairs, and in my portfolio of external territories, put down anything contained by way of implication in that regard. We look back on our record with pride in human value terms in what was done for the nation.
—Order! I ask the Leader of the Opposition to get to the question.

—My question to the Prime Minister is: Will he accept, in the spirit of what he put down by my endorsement of it, the right nevertheless of any Opposition at any time to ask legitimate questions of the policies of his Government? Secondly, will he ensure that the honourable member for Hotham withdraws the remarks that he made against us during Question Time.

—The answer to the first part of the Leader of the Opposition's question is yes. In respect of the second part I must say that I did not hear what the honourable member for Hotham said. The responsibility for the conduct of the House in these matters is in your hands, Mr Speaker. However, let me say that we did go through an emotional period in the House then and probably people on both sides of the House said things that would better have been left unsaid. I simply say to members on both sides, and I include my own in that, that I hope, in the spirit of what I have said and what the Leader of the Opposition has said, that there will be no more statements of a kind which will in any way raise this issue beyond where it should be, that is, it should be a non-issue in this House and in this country.
—What about legitimate questions?
—I was talking about the latter area. I answered the first question by saying yes.
—The honourable member for Hotham has sought my indulgence for a certain purpose. I think that when honourable members hear the purpose they will appreciate that I should grant him indulgence.

—I was just challenged by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to withdraw some remarks I made. I do not intend to withdraw anything but I want to apologise to you, Mr Speaker, and to the House for the probably temperamental behaviour I displayed. I want the House to understand that I was born in Europe. I came from Yugoslavia and have been here a long time. I am one of the products of Arthur Calwell's immigration policies. I settled here more than 30 years ago. My parents are buried in my electorate and my grandchildren are growing up here. At a young age I witnessed, during the Nazi occupation of Yugoslavia, racism at its worst. I have seen people put to death because of their nationality and race and, of course, I am offended by the behaviour of the Opposition which wants to introduce--
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. I am not going to put up with this and neither are my people.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I say to the honourable member for Hotham that he was given indulgence for a purpose. He should not use it in a partisan manner.
—I withdraw the generalisation because I have seen people as victims of generalisation; let me put it that way. But there are some members--
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham should not debate the issue. He has been given indulgence.
—That is how it started in Nazi Germany-by just this sort of attitude. He is right.
—Order!

—There are 72 different nationalities living in my electorate of Hotham. They are all Australians, and their children will be Australians, no matter where they come from. I resent and find offensive any imputation that people of different origins, whether they come from Ireland or Yugoslavia, or from Vietnam for that matter, are any different. I have seen people put to death because of such imputations. Mr Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to move a motion in regard to immigration. Is leave granted?

—The Leader of the House was going to indicate to me, in the spirit of bipartisanship of which the Prime Minister spoke before, the matter to be raised. The Leader of the House indicated that he would tell me what it was about. I will not give leave until I know what I am supposed to be giving leave for.
—Mr Speaker, I have explained--

—Order! The Leader of the House and the Leader of the Opposition will resume their seats. The procedures of the House cannot go on in this manner. I ask the Leader of the House to make clear what he wants to do, for the information of the Leader of the Opposition. We will proceed from there.
—It is my intention to move 'that this House supports the Government's continued adherence to the long-standing non-discriminatory immigration policy of this country'.
—Is leave granted to suspend Standing Orders?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr YOUNG

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs from moving forthwith:
That this House supports the Government's continued adherence to the long- standing non-discriminatory immigration policy.

I think that the way in which I have placed the motion will give sufficient numbers of speakers from both sides of the House the opportunity to partake in a rational debate on this matter. It will enable the Government, through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) and other speakers, to outline what has occurred since March of 1983, when we were elected, and in some way will enable members on the Opposition side to outline what occurred during their reign of government between 1975 and 1983 and the way in which they may feel that that policy has been deviated from now. I think that will be much more constructive and beneficial than allowing the matter of public importance to come on later. That is why I so move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House supports the Government's continued adherence to the long- standing non-discriminatory immigration policy.

I welcome this opportunity today, if not the way it has come about, to explain to the House fully and formally what the Government's immigration policies, which are applied in a non-discriminatory manner, are all about. I may not have all the information that I normally have for a formal statement. Nevertheless, I am quite prepared to stand before my colleagues of both sides of the House today and to the best of my ability inform them of what the Government has said before and what it will continue to say in the future. I should preface these explanations with a few remarks about the issues and the way that this matter has come up. I am concerned that the Opposition-I am not saying this in an inflammatory way-has to some extent been involved in a disturbing campaign in this House, a campaign which, to be charitable, can be misconstrued.

The fact is, as I said at Question Time, that I welcome a debate upon immigration policy. I suggest that it be an informed debate, not an irrational debate or one full of invective and not one which encourages in the community hatred from bigots and racists. I suggest that some of the comments made in this House and on national television-I do not say this in an inflammatory way-by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) have not really helped the situation. I am sure that all honourable members agree with that. I cannot see that what we have done in our immigration policy has been an example of a radical and dangerous turn to the Left. In fact, I defy any reasonable person to explain to me how the taking of large numbers of right wing conservative refugees, many of them economic refugees, I suppose, from Vietnam, is in any way radical or leftist. Certainly most of them do not vote Labor, that is for sure.

The honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) knows that. I will explain later in this speech exactly how the program came about and what we have done. But I am getting ahead of myself. Just let me say that there is no justification for the statements that the shadow Minister and the Opposition have made. Nor is there any justification for the statements that Professor Blainey has made. However, I do not dispute his right to say them because I am not a racist. I will not say that anyone in this House or anyone outside in the community who wants to start a debate on this matter is a racist simply because that person wants to discuss the issues. That is not what I am saying. I am saying that if we are to have a debate let it be an informed debate in the best interests of this House and the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. This debate is about immigration policy. There is no need to talk about the history of the refugee program.
—Order! That is not really a point of order.

—That is part of immigration policy, I suggest. I suggest also that I take a few minutes to refute the claims of the Big Brother Movement because that in a way is what has created and instigated this debate today. I refer to its statements in the community and those it has made through its representatives in this House. I say to that Movement that we are not anti-British. We are not pro- Asian and I am not looking forward, as it seems to believe, to the Asianisation of Australia; not at all. As I said at Question Time I do note that there is some element of sexual discrimination in the Movement's activities because since 1925 it has brought into Australia 12,000 young males and only one girl. What it was doing might have been all right in the halcyon days when we were bringing in tens of thousands of independent immigrants, but we are not doing that any more. To allow the Big Brother Movement to be an organisation acting outside the parameters of government, determining its own standards of entry, is just not on in a situation of considerably reduced numbers. The former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Balaclava, well knows all that. On 19 August 1981, he met with the President of the Movement, Brigadier Sir John Pagan, who, I think, used to be the President of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The former Minister said that we would not be able to continue with financial assistance to the movement. He further advised Sir John that, because the movement could be seen as discriminatory in both terms of source and its restriction to males, he did not think that new financial arrangements would be acceptable to the Government. The next Minister, the then honourable member for Petrie, reversed all that. He had my Department send a cable to London which stated that the Big Brother Movement was to interview and process its own nominees; the standards and criteria to be applied were to be decided by the movement; and the movement was not bound to ensure that the qualifications of its nominees would be recognised in Australia.

Quite frankly, I think that should end the debate. We cannot have any organisation choosing and processing its own migrants and putting them up to the Government on an accept or reject basis. We cannot have that. If we do we will have to give the same facilities, if requested, to many other migrant organisations in Australia, including those that represent the Greeks, the Italians, the Yugoslavs, the Asian countries and so on. I hope that I have answered the assertions of the Opposition. I will not accept that what we have done is an example of anti-British or pro-Asian behaviour. I have simply removed the positive discrimination in favour of the Big Brother Movement. It is not an example of anti-British behaviour or pro-Asian settlement. That is simply nonsense.

I now want to address my attention to the remarks by Professor Blainey. I said that he had a right to say what he liked and that the community and this House would judge him. He said that the Government is letting in too many Asians. I say that that is a result of non-discriminatory policies in family reunion and refugee policies and in other areas such as skilled migration, lesser programs and business migration. Professor Blainey is really saying to me, in reply: ' Well, if that is so it may very well be, but what I want you to do, because it is producing that result, is change the components, change the intake, change the set-up altogether, so that you do not get too many Asians'. He is saying that if we do not apply all of these selection procedures globally and there is discrimination with the result that it produces too many Asians, we should simply change the situation. What he is saying is 'Cut out the refugees; turn them down to a negligible number and reduce the family reunion program', or else he is saying 'Let us have quotas or tougher selection measures'.

Because I know that my own people support me I say to the Opposition: 'The day there is a government, any government of any colour, in this nation which goes back to imposing quotas under a global migration program, say, a family reunion program, or makes the selection procedure tougher for brothers and sisters, spouses, aged parents or non-dependent children to enter this country, or imposes a tougher system of selection on Asian people within those categories that apply for Europeans then we are gone. We are half way back to white Australia'. We cannot have that. Just what are members of the Opposition saying? What would they like us to do? Would they like us to cut the family reunion program and the refugee program? The States do not want us to cut business migration.

Before I conclude I will inform honourable members of the procedures that are adopted. I will tell them what it is all about. Looking at the clock, perhaps I should start to do that now. We have concentrated on family reunion and refugees . We have increased the number of family reunions from 27,000 to 40,000-plus in one year. We had a mandate to do that. We have kept up the refugee program. I said that we would take 18,000. This year we are taking 17,300. I agree with what the former Government did regarding the Indo-Chinese. I do not remember which Minister was responsible. I do not think that the honourable member for Balaclava, who is sitting opposite, endorsed the program-I will mention the history of it in a minute-but he certainly carried it on and the former Minister started it up. Two or three years ago that program was at its peak, when 15,500 Indo-Chinese came into this country after fleeing Vietnam, and later, Cambodia and Laos. There was nothing going on except resettlement. Last year 12,500 Indo- Chinese came into the country. This year, 1983-84, we have toned the figure down to 10,000, not for racist reasons but for other reasons that I will now explain.

The history of the program should be well known. It arose out of the Vietnam war, the fact that many people fled Vietnam and the fact that later the Khmer fled from Cambodia into Thailand as a result of the conflict in Cambodia. Since the Geneva Conference of 1979 it has never been anything but a resettlement program. Nothing else was tried. At first there was no orderly departure from Vietnam, no attempt at voluntary repatriation and no attempt at local integration. It was all resettlement, as honourable members know, by five major nations-Canada, Australia, the United States of America and, to a lesser extent, France and the United Kingdom. But Australia was always the biggest nation in terms of per capita acceptance. It still is, although it is reducing its intake a bit now. As I have said, we have reduced it from 15,500 people to 10,000 people-not because I am crooked on the Asians; not at all. It is because I could see that resettlement alone was not the answer.

I went to an intergovernmental consultation in Hawaii last year and consulted with the Americans, the Japanese, the Canadians and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as to what we should do. I later engaged directly in consultations with Dr Mochtar of Indonesia, the Prime Minister of Thailand and the Foreign Ministers of Malaysia and Singapore. I then consulted with Paol Hartling, the High Commissioner. We came to the conclusion that we had to start doing things other than just resettle. Otherwise it would go on for ever, honestly. So we paid more attention to orderly departure. The former Government, to its credit, started that off. But we have accentuated it. We have said: ' Orderly departure is better than disorderly departure. Let us turn the refugee tap down, discourage the boat people from leaving. We will have a family reunion base to the policy here in Australia, call it orderly departure and turn up the wick on family reunion'. That is what we have done for the Vietnamese. As the refugee figures have come down from 15,500 to 10,000-they will perhaps come down a little more this coming year-we have turned up the wick on orderly departure, from nothing to 600 last year, to 20,000 this year and to a few more next year. Gradually, as one area of refugees comes down, we will build it into the family reunion program.

I said that as a result of the policies of the previous Government there are now 80,000 to 90,000 Indo-Chinese in Australia. We have continued the program that brought them here. Those people now have a family reunion base. We are moving the refugee target down and lifting the family reunion program. That is proper as long as there is not another blow-up over there. The situation in Cambodia is in the hands of the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, the Vietnamese and, I hope, my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). I will not comment too much on that except to say that we want to see more voluntary repatriation-I stress, voluntary-back to Laos . That is already occurring under the auspices of the UNHCR. If possible we want to see voluntary repatriation back into Cambodia with aid being directed at the villages, not just at the border, to attract that voluntary repatriation. In other words, we are trying to do more than just resettle refugees.

The point is that we already have 90,000 people from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia in Australia now and they are entitled to family reunion, as is anyone else. That is one of the reasons why we are getting more Asian people here under the family reunion orderly departure program. They have their rights. We have turned up the program slightly. There are about 30,000 nominees in the pipeline. I stress that only 2,000 have been accepted this year. Far from giving the Indo- Chinese favouritism over the British, we are actually saying that because the administrative procedure is slow the option is to take only the children, parents and spouses of people already in Australia and no brothers and sisters. But we do not say that to the British or to Europeans; of course not. If there is any discrimination, it is a discrimination built in through administrative procedures on the Vietnamese side. It is not that we are anti-Asian, and we are certainly not pro-Asian. They are some of the things that we have done.

We have also diversified the refugee program. Our program has given refuge to people from the Middle East, including Lebanon, Sri Lanka and Chile. This year we have taken 1,500 Lebanese, 500 Sri Lankans, 300 White Russians, 200 East Timorese-some of them from Portugal-400 Assyrians from Athens and Rome, 400 others from the Middle East and 300 Chileans. The former Government took only 50 from the whole of Latin America while our total this year from Latin America is 1,300, and we have taken 200 of those from El Salvador. They are some of the things that we are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about from Turkey?

—Yes, we will take them too if they can establish a case. We have diversified in that way. Let me explain to honourable members the actual components of the intake. When the Government took office the emphasis was on skilled migration. The categories were called occupational demand, business migration and labour shortage. In total I think the former Government accepted about 40,000 in 1982-83 under its program; 27,000 were accepted under the family reunion program. The rest were refugees and a few in business migration. We changed the emphasis and we have taken 40,000 under family reunion this year and only 11,000 all up in the occupational demand and business migration categories. We think there will be an increase in that in the future. I think the business migration category is warranted provided we can keep it well monitored. I also think there is a case to increase skilled migration slightly under the new system of selection which the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, and I have expounded, called the occupational shares system where we will attempt to predict the future needs in certain key areas rather than look to the past and rely on Commonwealth Employment Service figures.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no discrimination in the business migration program. About 2,000 applicants will come in this year. The criteria is that they live permanently in Australia, that they introduce new industries to Australia, employ permanent residents or citizens of Australia and preferably introduce new technologies. All of this is not new. I predict a moderate upsurge in business migration in the next year. I hope Opposition members will support that because their colleagues in the States have made it plain to me that they do. They are all the things we have done.

I repeat that we have allowed an increase in the family reunion category. We have reduced to a certain extent the reliance on skilled, English speaking, rich family reunion aspirants and given the battlers a chance. We will not turn it down too low so that we take a whole lot of elderly and unskilled people. We cannot do that. But everyone in Australia knows that people who are not so skilled, not so rich and who may be middle aged at least now have a chance for family reunion that they did not have before. We cannot take them all, but we have tried. The increase in family reunion has gone up by 13,000. There have been problems in category C mainly because people cannot comply with a job offer and because there has been a lessening demand from certain European countries. We are looking at some measures to try to lift up the numbers of younger skilled people from, say, Europe.

I hope that honourable members opposite will at least pay me the credit of being able to put a fairly comprehensive statement down at short notice as to what we are all about. I challenge them to say whether they think they could have done better.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department wrote it two days ago.

—No, I have hardly looked at a note, as I have told the honourable member. (Extension of time granted) I was saying that we have increased the family reunion intake, diversified the intake of refugees, kept up the business migration program and taken a whole lot of other initiatives that are generally supported in the community. I said that there was no evidence of anti-British or anti-European behaviour in any of this, that it was not pro-Asian in an intended way but certain results were coming through due to the former Government's policies and our continuing with the refugee policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that there was probably a case to increase the numbers of younger skilled people who would possibly come from Europe, the United Kingdom, other places and Asia too-as part of the family reunion program in category C-without a job offer. I flagged that I would like the Government to look at that. I think it is probably a good idea. I am not saying that because I want to drag in more Europeans to balance the intake of Asians; I am saying that because I think as a result of the upturn in the economy due to the Hawke Labor Government we probably need a few more younger skilled migrants who would be good settlement risks. We can look at that.

I want to conclude on the note that I introduced in Question Time today. I refute the evidence that the Opposition tries to give of this massive upturn in Asian entry. Let me put the situation on the record. I will go back to 1980-81. I hope I do not weary honourable members with figures but I do think this is necessary. Total settler arrivals in 1980-81 were 22.47 per cent from Asia, 18.4 per cent from Europe and 28.4 per cent from the United Kingdom and Ireland. Total settler arrivals for 1981-82 were 22.4 per cent for Asia, 21 per cent for Europe and 32.7 per cent for the United Kingdom and Ireland. I am not dealing with other countries, I am just comparing Europe, Asia and the United Kingdom. Total settler arrivals in 1982-83 were 26.37 per cent from Asia, 21.2 per cent from Europe and 29.3 per cent from the United Kingdom and Ireland. For the half year 1983-84, the last section for which I have figures, 33.2 per cent were from Asia, 16.8 per cent were from Europe and 28.9 per cent were from the United Kingdom and Ireland. That is a 0.4 per cent fall from the United Kingdom and Ireland for total settler arrivals.

The figures for sub-category C, which is mainly brothers and sisters, was slightly different. The figures for the United Kingdom and Ireland fell from 50 per cent to 37 per cent. This is from 1982-83 to the half year of 1983-84. The figure for Asians rose from 12.2 per cent to 20.5 per cent. I stress that those are total settler arrivals, not applications or visa issues. That is the position. There is nothing very savage or outstanding about those figures which indicate a swing from Britian and Europe to Asia on the basis of sheer political bias against the British or sheer political bias against Europeans in favour of Asians. We have not done that.

Before I conclude I thank the House for allowing me the extra few minutes, and I will not try honourable members' patience by taking up all the time available. All of the categories and all of the selection procedures that the former Government implemented have been continued. We are the inheritors of the former Government's policies. We have moderated the entry and selection criteria for family reunion to give the battlers a better chance and I have diversified the refugee intake to get away from a total reliance on Indo-China. That is what we have done. We have inherited the former Government's policies. We said we would give more emphasis in future on family reunion, and we did that. The figures relating to those who entered Australia under that program have gone up to 43, 000 from 27,000. I am not quite sure yet what the final figure will be, but I do not think it will be under 40,000-from 27,000. The number of refugees to enter Australia is about the same. The big difference is that the number of Indo- Chinese refugees has been reduced and we have taken more people from other troubled areas of the world, because they are in trouble and because they have a base of community support here in Australia. I refer to the Lebanese, the Sri Lankans, the Chileans, the Salvadorans and even the Assyrians. I refer also to the conservative Assyrians in Athens and Rome. We have even inherited the previous Government's White Russia program, but I think that will probably be terminated because I do not think there are many more White Russians left in China.

We have continued with the business migration program. The same criteria prevail except that I am a whole lot tougher about what we would term to be bodgie inquiries. I think that is proper. This program should be monitored more toughly to see that business applicants are not just coming in to get a permanent entry card, buy a block of flats, then shoot through and run around the world for the rest of their lives. They may come here if they have the capital, the technology, a worthwhile project and if they employ Australians or permanent residents. I have said that we will tune up the skilled migration program and make it more responsive to future needs. We will not look back to the past and get a list of categories from the Commonwealth Employment Service which say that six months ago such employment categories were in short supply. That is the system I inherited.

I had experiences last year and the year before as the steel industry turned down in Wollongong of seeing United Kingdom migrants who had been brought out here under the employer nominated scheme sacked three months after they arrived by the Australian Iron and Steel Ltd, at Port Kembla. This occurred after they had sold their houses, their cars and everything they owned in England. That is the sort of employer nomination occupation demand system that I inherited. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and I have decided, and Cabinet has agreed, to slot the immigration skilled labour intake into a total labour force and educational planning processes whereby we will attempt to predict over the next three to five years the numbers which will be required in about 60 key areas. That is a far better system than looking back to the past.

I think that I should conclude my case there. Other speakers from the Opposition side and from my side of the House will take up these very important national issues. Let me conclude on this note: Remember what we can do in a spirit of consensus and bipartisanship on issues on which we are not divided. In the last two or three months in this House and in the community the Government and I have had to endure attacks which were not genuinely based. I hope I have refuted such arguments today. I do believe that honourable members opposite are entitled to participate both in this place and out in the community in an informed debate on anything including the issue of immigration and ethnic affairs policies, but for God's sake let it be an informed debate. Please do not climb on the bandwagon of all those people who come out of the woodwork when they see misstatements being made. We are not racist. We are not pro-Asian or anti-British and we are not anti-European. The Government is committed to a total non-discriminatory policy in all of those components of the migration program that I have described. They will be implemented under global pre- selection criteria which will be applied without fear or favour, whether a person be Vietnamese, French or British.

It proves only one thing-that some people are misusing statistics. There are statistics, statistics and other people, and the other people are the ones who are quite dishonestly manufacturing the immigration debate. One does not expect a statistician's punctiliousness in the application of statistics in this place in the normal course of debate but in the context in which we have now been cast, where the issue of racial tolerance is coming to centre stage, I suggest that the way in which those figures are presented ought to be more carefully addressed; otherwise something that I believe none of us want will take place.

I have been here for 23 years and have had many disappointments in that 23 years, as well as many joys. It has mostly been interesting. As I have said, one learns the mood of this place when one has had many experiences. I sat here today very silently because for a few moments I was absolutely apprehensive. Something ugly flared for a few moments. This place is a microcosm of the community; we represent a broad spectrum of the people living in Australia who make this great country tick. If we explode like that, imagine how the rest of the community can explode if it is misled as a result of some sort of misunderstanding. I repeat that I prefer to believe it was all a misunderstanding.

But let us understand certain facts that are burdening themselves upon us. We live in a part of the world in which, in the literal sense, we are an anomaly. We are an anomaly because ethnically we are caucasian. People all around us are Asian; lots of things have been happening in our region and will continue to happen, which will determine their own outcome. It is to the credit of Malcolm Fraser and the conservative Government he administered that when the so-called boat people started arriving on our shores he repudiated the blandishment to shove them off, to indulge in some sort of racist reaction sought by a limited number in the community. If I can say so, I suppose at the risk of sounding a little vain, I believe I also displayed that quality as Leader of the Opposition . I was subjected to a great deal of pressure, outside the Parliament, from narrowly based groups in the community, to take up a racist position. It was said that it would be good for votes. Maybe it was but I doubt it. I have a higher regard, however, for my fellow Australians than to believe that and moreover, the last thing I want to do is to divide the country. It has been divided unnecessarily too often in the past. Australians accepted these people because we are humane and compassionate and understand that we are the product of migration flows. Our forefathers built from this very unpromising country one of the greatest countries in the world. There is a sense of fair play, of egalitarianism, among us. If I can parenthetically observe the quote from the base of the Statue of Liberty in the United States of America, which has always impressed me, it states:
Give me your tired, your poor,
Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free . . .

I believe that in Australia, without any flamboyance or ornamental style, we have done that in a very practical way. Let me address a central factor. The official statistics show that in 1982-83, in round figures, 24,500 Asian migrants came to Australia. Of that number, 12,758-13,000 in round figures-were refugees. Does anyone in this Parliament, does any fair-minded citizen of this great country, stand and declare that we should not have accepted them? I wear as a badge of pride the way in which Australians have been prepared to accept the down-trodden, the excluded and the jettisoned from the rest of the world and help make them great citizens of this country. That was more than half the total number. If we accept that we do not have a discriminatory immigration policy, we must accept that the principles applying in one place apply elsewhere. So inevitably we have the momentum of family reunion. Nearly 7,000 Asian people are involved in that; about 25 per cent of the total. So we have just on 20,000 out of a total of a bit over 24,000 who are either refugees or family reunionists- that is, more than 80 per cent in the two categories. Do honourable members opposite propose that those two categories be cut back?

As I said a little earlier, when I listened to the debate and became a little uneasy about the direction it was taking, I thought that perhaps my colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs had made drastic repositionings of the content of our immigration policy; that perhaps these nasty things were true. When I look at the bar chart the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs produced and from it glean the pattern over time, I find that there is no truth in this at all. I find that the pattern is a variable thing. But what is clearly implanted in that pattern is the fact that, because of events in Vietnam in the 1960s and 1970s, because of the change of government there and because of the intolerance of that government, people fled. They fled because they found the system unacceptable. A lot of them are still fleeing. A lot have been left adrift in the South East Asian area looking for places to live. They are creating pressures on the countries of that region which, in turn, are applying pressure to this country. Are we proposing to ignore that? If we ignore it, have we thought of the consequences? (Extension of time granted)

We would no longer have the regulated flow of these people. It stands to the eternal credit of Malcolm Fraser and his Government, including the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) among other immigration Ministers, that these people were accepted by us. That practice has been continued by the present Minister for Immigration. What happens then? I will tell the House. Many of the people who are coming here under the regulated system will make their way in other ways. The people who are in those forlorn refugee camps in South East Asia, a burden on the countries of that region-we make our contribution, but it is still a burden-will seek to come here in other ways. They will start arriving as they started arriving in the initial movement that took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boat people.

—Yes, boat people. What happens then? Will we erect a fortress around our shores to try to repel them? That is nonsense. Would we be so intolerant? We would then have an immigration policy over which we had no control at all; we would have no selection procedures at all. We should make no mistake about it! Some of the largest, most powerful countries in the world are re-assessing their attitudes towards Vietnamese, Laotians, Kampucheans, migrant flows. What sort of pressure would that place on us if such countries decided to jettison policies under which some sharing takes place? I do not propose to explore it any further than that. All I am saying is that we live in an extraordinarily complex part of the world loaded with difficulties that had not been seen in earlier generations . The world has changed; our region has changed. We can no longer go on the way that perhaps was accepted a couple of decades back. The situation is totally different.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that there are any racists in this Parliament. I have seen no evidence of racism. I believe that what happened this afternoon was an unfortunate explosion of temperament through misunderstanding all round. I hope that we do not see it again. I hope that the debate in the community continues, because it helps to focus the Government's attention in a more positive way on how the community feels about these things. But I hope that the debate will not take place according to the views of a minority of extremists who jump in and exploit this situation. Indeed, I have seen it in my electorate, where I have seen signs wanting me impeached for treachery because of my views about the rights of all people in particular Asian-Australians. I am inspired by the New Testament, even though I am an atheist. The principles are highly relevant today . I believe that most people are inspired by those sorts of qualities and principles, wherever they come from; principles of tolerance and respect for the uniqueness and importance of each and every human life.

The final thing I want to say is that the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) was kind enough to challenge me, not in a nasty way but in a helpful way, to explain views I have expressed in respect of immigration and the future of this country. I have elsewhere said that it is my view that this country would be best served with a population of 50 million people. I have never stipulated what sort of population when I have explicitly addressed myself to that point. It is a view which is contended by many people, including many here in my own organisation. It is a personal view which I have expressed over the years. It is based solely on certain economic assumptions that I work according to. I believe we need 50 million people so that we have a basic market available in this country which will allow our manufacturing industry to manufacture with more confidence. If it has a large domestic market, the overrun for exports is a much lower proportion of its total output. Therefore, what it is producing is not exposed to so much risk on world markets through erratic pricing policies on such markets. That is a simple proposition. There are of course other considerations which are ancillary to it.

It is true that I have also expressed my view elsewhere about changes which I think could take place. Those changes would to some extent change the colour of people's skin in this community. I stressed that it is a personal view and that it comes from changes which are under way. It is the sort of thing that would take 100 or 200 years. That is what I have said and I accept responsibility for that exclusively. It is wrong to attribute that view to anyone else in this Party. I am not aware of anyone else in the Party saying it. It is unfortunate that that sort of comment may inflame this community. If that is so, it is not the sort of comment I will make again. But I will not retreat from my belief that all men and women are created equal and should not be discriminated against on artificial grounds or on grounds over which they have absolutely no control. Too many Jews, Catholics, Protestants, too many ordinary people in the history of mankind, have died excruciating deaths because of the bigotry and intolerance of a few who have wrongly managed to get control of a situation. That will not happen in this country. The basic qualities of Australians are too decent to allow that to happen. But let us not allow this country to be divided unnecessarily on an artificial or spurious issue. Let us attend to this debate in a constructive and dignified way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in his speech this afternoon made the essential point that we do not want to divide the country. I think that everyone in this House would agree with that sentiment . We do not want to divide the country. We would all acknowledge the right of anyone, regardless of race, creed or colour, to be equally treated. I happened to be the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in this Parliament during that time to which the Minister for Foreign Affairs referred. I acknowledge and remember very well the situation when Australia was faced with a challenge and a dilemma as to how to react to the enormous human problem that was posed, not only for Australia but also for the whole world, by the exodus of people as a result of the policies of the Government of Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia responded to that challenge in a way which, I believe, provided an example for the rest of the world. In fact, we initiated discussions at the United Nations which expanded the world's appreciation of the problem and expanded the number of countries which were prepared to receive and accept refugees. Thus I reject absolutely any criticism of this side of the Parliament, of my Party or of the National Party, or any suggestion that the Opposition has a racist approach to the problems that this country faces or to the requirements of immigration.

When considering this entire question, we really should go back to basics. We have to ask ourselves whether we need immigration or want it. If we do need and want it how do we organise it? We have to accept the proposition that there are some within the community who would suggest that immigration should be cut off entirely straight away. I personally reject that situation out of hand, because I share with the Minister for Foreign Affairs a belief that the population of this country should be expanded. I do not share with the Minister for Foreign Affairs his formula for achieving that expansion. Whilst he has just said that it is his own personal view, in the remarks attributed to him and reported earlier this year there does seem to be a suggestion that the immigration program should be a response by Australia to overcrowded situations in other countries. I reject that proposition entirely. Immigration to Australia can never be the answer to overpopulation problems in other countries; nor should it be seen in that way. I do not know of any immigration Minister in the past who has supported that proposition. Unfortunately, it seems to be the basis of the remarks made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he talked about a multiracial 50 million population in Australia.

The fact of the matter is that those people who become overexcited about the multiracial characteristics of Australian society forget that we have always been a multiracial society. We are, though, predominantly British and European in our population composition. That is a factor which should not be forgotten and which must be taken into account by any government of any political persuasion and by any immigration Minister. If as a result of immigration policies rapid changes in the population composition of Australia occur, inevitably the person introducing those policies and the government supporting those policies are causing trouble within the total community in Australia, because too rapid changes will excite comment, will excite opposition and will delay the effects of integration. They will make it more difficult for people coming to this country effectively to settle in this country.

We have to consider the composition of the migrant intake to have a real appreciation of what it means, because too many people see the migrant intake as just one amorphous blob. It is not. It comprises various sectors which the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) referred to earlier this afternoon.

Let me reiterate those main characteristics of the migration intake. There is the family reunion section of the intake, to which the Minister has referred, and that is a most important section of the intake. It is one which needs to be looked at extremely carefully because an apparent small change in the criteria for entry in family reunion has a very major effect and shift in the composition of the migrant intake. That is exactly what has happened as a result of the change in policies introduced by this Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is quite proper and appropriate for this side of the Parliament and for people in the community to raise and debate that issue, to look at the effects of that change and to comment upon the effects of that change.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the problem? Tell me: What is the problem?

—I will deal with the problem in just a moment. The other aspects of the immigration intake are the skilled migrant intake and the other area which has been referred to quite extensively today, that is, the humanitarian aspect or the refugee sector. There are other minor sectors but those are the three main ones. There are two aspects relating to migration which need to be taken into account. People want to come to Australia, and they are very important. We can at no one time welcome all the people who wish to come to Australia because every year there are simply too many who apply to come to this country. We cannot accept all those people who wish to come. If we cannot accept all those who wish to come, we must make choices. There must be selectivity. Whether one likes it or not, decisions must be made as to those who shall come to Australia-who will be accepted and who will be rejected. To talk about a totally non-discriminatory policy is really a nonsense in the absolute because while we may have a non-discriminatory policy in terms of the people applying we have a selective policy in terms of the people who are admitted for entry. That is quite proper.
—But that is eligibility.

—It is eligibility, but we have to be selective regarding those who apply. That is the point I make. The second point I make-this is a most important aspect of the entire migration program which is often neglected and forgotten, particularly by Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-is that there are people already in Australia who have very strong views about migration to this country, and there are various views. There are some who would totally reject any future entry. There are some who would restrict the entry to certain groups. There are some who would put a stress on family reunion. There are some who would put a stress on the skilled migrant intake. There are some who would say: 'We really do not need those people. The people in greatest need are the refugees and we should concentrate almost entirely on them'.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to have an acceptable migration program we must have acceptance by the people who are already in Australia. If we build up a situation within this country in which the resident population stands against the policies being implemented by the Government, then we will get trouble. We can rail against it, we can say that it is wrong, racist and all the dreadful things that characterise it, but the fact remains that, human nature being what it is, if a migrant intake policy is not acceptable to the people of Australia then we are building trouble within the community.
