That has to be recognised. We can be as pure and as idealistic as we like, but we have to be practical. I suggest that that is the area in which this Government and this Minister are causing a great deal of problem and are exciting a great deal of concern within the Australian community.

We are, in fact, a basically British and European based society. We should remember that. The great institutions of this country have been handed to us because of our predominantly British tradition. This Parliament in which we stand, and in which we are proud to stand, is a British tradition. The British concepts of law apply in this country. If the Government intends to attack those traditional institutions which characterise our society, traditions which have developed in this country and have been accepted by all who have come here and live here, there will be problems. In 1979, as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I made a speech which I think covered a great deal of what this debate is all about. I said:

We delude ourselves if we do not accept that there will be increasing pressures on Australia to take increasing numbers of persons, refugees and otherwise, from countries which have not been traditional sources of migration to Australia. If we do wish to maintain a population composition not greatly different from the present, we shall have to pay much more attention to migration from our traditional source countries than we have during this decade. It is not the most propitious time from the employment angle to be suggesting and acting on this approach but the longer term consequences of not taking action are momentous and must be faced.
In fact, I suggest it may be in our economic interests in the longer term to embark on a new immigration program much as we did immediately after the Second World War.
That is another argument. Let me go back to the essential points of that statement:

. . . will be increasing pressures on Australia to take increasing numbers of persons, refugees and otherwise, from countries which have not been traditional sources of migration to Australia. If we do wish to maintain a population composition not greatly different from the present, we shall have to pay much more attention to migration from our traditional source countries than we have during this decade.

It is up to the Government and this Minister to say clearly and directly to the people of this nation whether they wish to depart from the traditional population composition of this country. If the Minister does wish to do so, let him say. If he does not, he will have to alter his present migration programs and policies because, quite simply, the implementation of the present policies will ensure quite a marked change in the longer term from the present population composition of this country. That is the question he must answer. That is the question the Government must answer. If they do wish to change the population composition, let them be honest enough to come out forthrightly and say so. They should not do it through the back door. They should state it clearly and honestly. They should tell the people that they want to change essentially the population composition of this country.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs asked me where his migration policies have brought about this situation. I will tell him quite directly. By expanding the family reunion criteria, as he has, he has inevitably brought about, because of the population characteristics in migrant source countries, a change in the composition of the intake. If he widens the family reunion criteria he will get an increased number of people from countries where the families are larger and where the tradition of family relationships is much stronger than in the sort of nuclear-type family which is mainly characteristic of British and European situations. If the Minister widens the family reunion criteria that is the effect it will have. What will be the other effect? He will increase the number of semi-skilled and unskilled migrants who come to Australia as a proportion of the total migrant intake. We all know that the semi-skilled and the unskilled sections of the working population are the hardest sections for which to find jobs. Those sections have the greatest unemployment in Australia at present. By doing what the Government has done it is not only changing the composition of the intake but also it is raising the number as a proportion of the semi-skilled and unskilled people who are coming into this country in direct competition with the semi-skilled and unskilled people already here who are seeking to find jobs.

In both those areas the Government is causing a disturbance. It is causing a degree of concern within the population. That concern is reflected in the criticism which has been directed, quite rightly, to this Minister and this Government about its migration policy. It is not a racist comment. It is a concern about a change in the population composition of Australia but not immediately, because it takes time. But, if continued, that will be the effect. That is the argument to which the Government has to respond. If it wants to change the population composition it should say so openly and properly and argue it out. We are quite prepared to do that. To suggest that anybody who questions the policy is a racist is simply to cheapen the entire debate, and it demonstrates very clearly an intellectual barrenness on the part of the Minister .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to take part in this debate. For three years as shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs opposite the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) I enjoyed meeting with many of the migrant organisations and ethnic community councils around Australia and getting an insight into the problems that Australia may have in relation to migration.

SPEECH.PARA: Since Federation, by and large this Parliament has had a bipartisan attitude to migration. This generation of parliamentarians would not be very proud of some of our record because for the vast majority of time since Federation there was a bipartisan attitude in favour of a white Australia policy. That white Australia policy, as the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said, gave us our British base, our British traditions, our British courts of justice and so forth . No one is arguing about that, but it was a bipartisan attitude back in the 1960s that eradicated the white Australia policy. It was a racist policy and both parties rejected any continuation of it.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) said over and over again in his speech that he is not a racist. We believe him, but the difficulty is that none of us can give ourselves titles. We will be judged on our conduct. There may well be-I say this as a word of warning, or wisdom, to the honourable member for Denison-racists outside who think he is a racist and who may be taking his campaign as some encouragement to carry out what they consider to be their rightful role in the community.

I give honourable members opposite a look at the sorts of posters that are appearing around Melbourne and Sydney in the campaign that is being waged by some people outside this Parliament in relation to Asian migration. In relation to our role in this Parliament, I always felt it enormously important-especially during those years from 1976 to 1982, because there were such important questions-that there should be very close liaison between the Minister and the shadow Minister, and there was. There were debates over the question of resources being handed over to ethnic communities but there was no bringing down to the Government a debate about our immigration policy. If ever the Australian Labor Party wanted to get down in the gutter and kick heads about immigration policy, the period from 1975 to 1982 was a golden opportunity for us to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you were marvellous and sensitive!

—No, no, let me complete this point. Between 1975 and 1980-81 there was a 1,500 per cent increase in Indo-Chinese refugees. That increase, from 1,000 to 15,000 refugees, was brought in under the Fraser Government. We supported it from the other side of the House. That was a major wrench to the Australian people. That was to bring about probably more discussion about where our immigration policies were headed than took place at any previous time in this Parliament. No one had seen such a major development or switch in our policies as occurred under the Fraser Government in agreeing to bring so many refugees into this country. We did it at the behest of the United Nations refugee program , in recognising where we lived and knowing that if we did not have some sort of orderly acceptance of refugees out of the camps around South East Asia they would be forced down here in their boats as they were in the latter part of the 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: It was because the Fraser Government set about accepting its quota of refugees under the United Nations program that the boat people stopped coming. If we had not done it we would still be inundated with boat people from South East Asia. It was not a very pleasant ride for the boat people out of Vietnam or wherever their camps may have been-in Thailand or Malaysia-to this part of the world. Our former ambassador to India, in his book entitled the Boat People, said that figures showed that up to half of the people who took to the boats out of Vietnam and out of the camps of South East Asia lost their lives. In 1982 the honourable member for Balaclava, then Minister, made a very important speech to this Parliament. He outlined to us who was recognised as and the definition of a refugee as follows:

A person who owing to a well founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country.

The only criticism that I as shadow Minister had of the former Minister was not that he was not giving recognition to that United Nations definition in accepting people from South East Asia but rather that he was being too restrictive. I felt that the Fraser Government should have recognised that there were refugees not just in South East Asia. The United Nations recognises that there are something like 15 million refugees in the world. There are refugees in Africa and Central America. I directed to the attention of the then Minister, who accepted it, that under our humanitarian program we ought to accept some of the refugees from other places in the world so that our refugee program did not look as if it was based entirely on South East Asia. Such a program is now well under way.

Let me again give the House the figures provided by the former Minister to give honourable members some idea of the impact the refugee program has had on our community. In 1974-75, at the end of the war, there were 1,000 Indo-Chinese refugees in Australia. In 1975-76 the intake figure was 1,000; in 1976-77, 1,300 ; in 1977-78, 7,000; in 1978-79, 12,000; in 1979-80, 15,200; in 1980-81, 15,700; in 1981-82, 14,000; and in 1982-83, 12,700. This year, 1983-84, the target is 10 ,000. Of course, the refugee number will continue to go down as the people who have come here as refugees, like the other half million refugees who have come to Australia from all over the world, become eligible to bring their families here. We know that the refugees who came here during the period from 1975 to 1982 were not able, because of the manner in which they reached this country, to come here in family units. They did not know where the rest of their family members were. I invite members of the Parliament to read the local Indo-Chinese newspaper, the Saigon Bell, which prints the names of families around the world. One of the reasons members of the Indo-Chinese community read their newspapers so assiduously is that they are trying to find out where the other members of their families finished up. They may have finished up dead. As the author of the book the Boat People said, 50 per cent of those who left in their boats died. But those refugees are entitled now, as they come here and take up their citizenship as soon as they are eligible, to bring their families here.

We are saying that the refugee number will go down and the family reunion number will go up. It is true that there has been in some instances in Europe, mainly because of the social security package which is available in so many European countries, a downturn in people wanting to come to live in Australia. Even after the Italian earthquake, we invited people out here, offering free fares and so forth to enable them to do so. But many of them came here, spent a few months and could not get back to Italy quick enough. So we are not putting up the same sort of proposition in terms of the Asian people as may have been the case in some instances in Europe.

We now have, as a result of the former Government's policies, 90,000 people here from South East Asia. The Labor Party supported that. I think it was a correct decision of the Australian Parliament, of both parties, to support a program that brought 90,000 Asian people here. We find when we talk to members of any ethnic community in Australia, whether from the Greek community, the Italian community or the Lebanese community, that they all say that the policy that they want adopted by this Parliament is one primarily in favour of family reunion. Above everything else, they want the right to bring immediate members of their family to live in this country.

If there is one thing that stands out about the success of our immigration program in this country it is the success of the family reunion program which has been so much a part of our total immigration package. Are we to say that there can be family reunion for Europeans but no family reunion for Asians? We cannot adopt a policy like that. We have to adopt a policy which does not discriminate against anybody. The fact that the 90,000 from South East Asia have come here so rapidly means that their demands for family reunion in most cases are going to be more acute than the family reunion demands of many other communities.

The former Minister and I, in our discussions in those years, agreed that it would not be good that the large community from Vietnam built up like that and the Laotians and the Cambodians be left in very small units. The only way these communities would be able to succeed and survive in the Australian atmosphere would be if they had rather substantial communities of their own so that they could assist each other, like former communities have done in building up their residences in Australia and in being able to settle. So we looked to supporting a policy of seeing that those communities were built up. No one should be surprised about what has occurred because the former Minister warned us what would occur in the years ahead.

It is very difficult to understand why the honourable member for Denison put forward his amendment. All we are saying is that this House should continue to support the Government's adherence to a policy that does not discriminate. I would have thought that everybody in the Parliament would have voted for that motion because-it is not our fault-the Liberal Party has yet to tell the world what its policy on immigration is. So we cannot vote for the amendment which might be aimed at getting a unanimous vote in the Parliament because we are not sure what the honourable member for Denison refers to in his amendment when he talks about proper immigration policies. Until he unfolds and tells the world what the Liberal Party's policies are going to be, we cannot support him. I do not know when he is going to do it but I would be interested to know the way in which he is going to alter the intake. I can tell him that from my dealings with the ethnic communities they would be more than anxious to find out what is going to happen.

From the chart that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) read out it is pretty clear to everybody what is happening in family reunion. Nothing disastrous is happening in this country so far as the intake is concerned. This Parliament, more than any other forum in Australia, has to be very careful not to set alight the desire of some of the minority outside who want to inflame the feelings of Australia, that all the economic ills we have lived through are at the behest of our policy of allowing the refugees to live in Australia.

In addition to being the shadow Minister for three years I also represent a district in Adelaide which has the only Commonwealth hostel. Most of the refugees who come to live in Adelaide-we have a very high proportion-live in Port Adelaide. At a couple of the primary schools, 25 to 30 per cent of the kids come from Indo-China.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same applies in Hindmarsh.

—And in the neighbouring electorate of Hindmarsh. The honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) have had direct experience with what is happening. These people are being integrated into the community so that they can take their places and be able to play a role in the future of this country. We supported what was a very brave decision by the Fraser Government, and there has been no radical departure from that. What we are feeling now-I ask the Opposition to recognise this-are the pressures of those 90,000 who came in under the former Government's policies to be able to bring their families here because some of them were split up, as honourable members would know, under rather horrendous circumstances. Some who wanted to come died trying to get here. Some are living in other parts of the world unable to get here. Those who are here deserve and are entitled to the same benefits that the immigration policy extends to every other person who lives in this country. We are big enough to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have taken half a million refugees into this country and they have become excellent citizens. Three million of the people in this country were born overseas. We have six million people in this country who have one parent born overseas. So we are not strangers to the intricacies of dealing with the relationships of people who come to live here. This Parliament and any individual in this Parliament cannot afford to set alight the flames that might still live in the hearts of a very small number of people who do want a racist debate on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that every member of this House would agree with the closing remarks of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) that no one wants to kindle the small but nonetheless quite active group who are indeed racist. I accept all that has been said by honourable members in this debate; there is no racist in this Parliament of whom I am aware. Indeed it is unfortunate that the debate did get to a certain degree of intolerance and that some suggestions of racism were made.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said at Question Time: One of the outstanding characteristics of this country has been that the immigration program went through a phase when it was racist, and bipartisanly so; then it got to the stage during Harold Holt's term onwards where it gradually became not only overtly non-racist, but in very practical terms, non-racist, and we are the richer for that, domestically and internationally. I do not believe there is anyone-I hope there is not-in this Parliament who would want it to be otherwise. I do not agree with the first sentence of an article in the Australian Financial Review on Monday but the rest of the article is true. I will quote what it says and then explain later. It states:

There has been a kind of conspiracy of silence on the subject of the discontent aroused by recent immigration, especially from Asia and most especially from Indo-China. This has not been a sinister conspiracy; on the contrary, it has been a tacit agreement between people of goodwill and the two sides of politics not to do anything to exacerbate potential racial tensions in Australia. At the same time, there has grown up a very unsavoury anti-immigrant and racist movement in some areas of Australia and in educational institutions. Perhaps it would have been better if the problems of immigration had been more openly discussed in the early days, instead of the running being left to those few who wanted to fish in the troubled waters of prejudice.

I disagree with the first sentence which said: 'There has been a kind of conspiracy of silence . . .', because as the statement goes on to imply, there has not been a conspiracy of silence; there was a bipartisan agreement which led to the change of policy and to what the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) rightly said is a non-discriminatory but highly selective policy. That was a matter of agreement. When the Special Minister of State-who preceded me in this debate and who was the shadow Minister at the time-went around this country with me and held public meetings everywhere--

TALK.START.PARA: —We got abused a few times too.

—We got abused a few times, but remarkably few. One of the saving graces of this country was that its politicians had proceeded at the same pace, as it were, as the bulk of the population. What was significant at the public meetings, which was well advertised, was that the racists who had the courage to express their opinions-I give them that much, and they were listened to in silence-were nonetheless such a small minority that we knew that the policy which we then drew up was acceptable to the people of this country. It was not, therefore, a conspiracy of silence. As I understand it, that is also the position of the Australian Democrats. So there is not a political party in this country which is racist or which will tolerate racism, if I may deliberately use that term.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) has made some changes to that policy. As the former Minister said, there was a natural tendency in the policy which he and I devised for there to be an increase in the number of persons from Asia, but it would not have increased the proportion of the intake had this present Government not reduced several categories.

I remind the House of a speech that I, as Minister, gave here on 29 October 1981. It is to be found at page 2704 of Hansard. I reported back on the review which the shadow Minister and I had made. I listed all the people with whom we consulted. I had consulted with the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs, on which the present Prime Minister served most constructively and on which the then shadow Minister, the present Special Minister of State who has just taken his seat, was also an active participant. That was the nature of things then. At the request of the then shadow Minister, I addressed a Caucus committee and explained our policies and heard the views of the entire parliamentary Labor Party. That was the extent of co-operation.

The present Minister has not called together the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs. He has not replaced it with anything else. He has taken no advice from all of the elements in the community which, in various forms, advised me and my predecessors. At least from the time of Mr Holt, there were advisory bodies representing the trade union movement, the employers and a variety of interested groups in the community. The present Minister has not reconstituted the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs and has never called it together. That is a major problem.

In presenting a bipartisan policy, I listed the various categories relating to immigration. The first category was family migration. We are all agreed, even in this debate, that that category remains intact and should remain intact. I think it is sad, if the present Government has felt that it has to respond to some of anti-Asian feeling of a minority, that it has cut back the entitlement of people from Indo-China who are Australian citizens and permanent residents to have full use of the family migration policies which we adopted. I think it is very sad. In the administration of the Minister's policy I think I see him reacting a little to this criticism. Arguably the best tandoori chef in Melbourne has been told that he has to go back from where he came, whereas under my administration I would have approved his staying. So it worries me that the Minister, as opposed to the Government and as opposed to anyone from the community who has advised him, has made some administrative changes and is continuing to do so. That does depart from the bipartisan spirit, and that is what is implied in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I repeat that he, amongst all of us, has denounced racism. He is not a racist. He was one of the great supporters of the Timorese special humanitarian program, amongst others. As I recall, that was hardly a vote winner in his electorate.

The second category was labour shortage and business migration. This is one of the categories which has suffered the greatest cuts. The Minister said that he thought the intake under this category in the last year of the Fraser Government was in the order of 40,000 people. I doubt that the figure was that high, but I am working from memory. In any event, my recollection is that even when the figure was in the mid-30,000s, no more than 11,000 or 12,000 people were actually seeking to enter the work force as skilled tradesmen; the rest were their dependants. If we take out of the migration program the Minister's figure of 40,000, and almost all of these people came from Europe, including Britain, we get a tremendous imbalance in the total proportion of Asians. This is because , quite properly, the Government had not reduced the Asian intake. Quite properly, the number of migrants under the refugee program is going down and the number under the orderly departure program is going up. That was the consequence of the policy which the Special Minister of State and I devised. If there were a cut in the skilled migration and business migration intake, which involved 40, 000 people who were predominantly European, of course, the presentation would be distorted.

The third category was independent migration. Again, this was an area where we wanted a variety of talents. Our policy was more stringent than our previous policy. Nonetheless, initially, the people most likely to satisfy this category numerically were of Caucasian origin. That category was cut also, not only without consultation with the Opposition but also without consultation with the community through the orthodox advisory channels. In the fifth category of special eligibility there was a sub-category relating to self-supporting retirees. Their numbers may not have been unusually large, but their intake has been cut. Changes have been made also to the change of status policy which is also set out in my speech. The fourth category related to refugees and special humanitarian programs, and that remains intact.
I think it is worth reminding the House of two paragraphs in my speech on 29 October 1981. I said:

At any one time the numbers of people wanting to migrate to Australia far exceed our capacity to receive migrants. In the year just past, 1980-81, for an intake of just over 110,000 new settlers our overseas posts had to process more than one million inquiries and applications.
That is true. That is why we had a highly selective policy. The speech continued :

Selection is therefore essential. Before the present selection system was announced in June 1978 a great deal of time and effort was put into examining the philosophy which should lie behind our immigration program. Honourable members will recall that the Government published a Green Paper as part of that examination. The present review and the changes I will be announcing today should be seen as building upon that work. The nine principles of our immigration policy-including the important global non-discriminatory nature of our programs-remain unaltered. The changes that will be made to the actual selection process have been made in the light of ongoing experience.

In line with its terms of reference the Committee of Review reported a wide range of community views on ways in which the present program might be altered. In responding to these, the Government was mindful that whatever the balance of its composition, the immigration program has an economic and cultural impact on the total community. In considering what changes needed to be made the Government did not see its task as one of reconciling minority views but rather as serving the totality of the national interest. There are a number of important issues which can be distilled from the Committee of Review's report. The report highlighted the fact that family and friends are important to settlement success and noted a strong demand for an acceptable family reunion system. It also highlighted concern that migrant entry criteria should be sensitive to current and foreseeable demands for labour. It underlined evidence that ability to get a job is vital to settlement success. In developing its proposals the Government was particularly mindful of these considerations.

The importance of that quotation is to remind the House of the extent to which I , as Minister, and the honourable member for Warringah, as my predecessor, consulted and the way in which the Green Paper was produced. As I said, the present Prime Minister was a member of the advisory committee which advised both of us in that work. When the Prime Minister was shadow Minister to me in the employment and industrial relations portfolio, he made a special plea in this House, which I supported, that we should not make immigration the scapegoat for the unemployment situation which had arisen. We all feel very strongly about that. Nonetheless, in gearing our family reunion policy, we insisted that those who were sponsored had a job to come to, and for the most part they did. Generally they came to a job that was not available to a person already here. It tended to be a job in a family business, where the work and the profits were shared, and it was not a job that would be available through the Commonwealth Employment Service or otherwise. Therefore, no Australian was being put out of a job; on the contrary, the increased demand for goods and services created by those persons helped to create more jobs.

One of the moves made by the present Minister was to do away with the job requirement. It seems to me that the main change he has made is to make it a little easier for people to qualify by increasing some of the points for skills, by dropping the English language requirement and by dropping the occupational demand for the family reunion program. I think that not only is that change going against the spirit of the carefully worked out bipartisan policy but also it is not fair either to the people coming without a job guarantee or to others who may believe that they should get a job first if one is going.

In respect of the Asian component of the migration, there is certainly not a dramatic increase under this Government. Indeed, it has gone exactly as I foreshadowed it would. Where the drop has come has been, of course, in respect of the Caucasian element of the intake. In 1980-81 the intake under family migration was 22,000 in round terms. (Extension of time granted) In 1982-83 it increased by 5,000. This was not a dramatic increase but, if in fact a large proportion of it is coming from Asia, it looks as though there is some higher intake than is otherwise the case. It is proportional.

Equally in the skilled labour and business area under what was then called the general eligibility category, which was slightly broader than the present one but nonetheless for present comparisons it is near enough the same, the intake in 1980-81 was 58,000. That number dropped to 32,000 in 1982-83. As that intake is primarily from Caucasian sources, of course that is what has thrown the balance out. So the purpose of the amendment to the Government's motion is simply to say that there ought to be a return to the bipartisan policy of 1981 in its total implementation. We are totally at one on refugees, totally at one on special humanitarian programs and totally at one on family migration. We differ only in the areas to which I have referred.

I think it is important that we recognise that this debate has, therefore, fuelled some anti-Asian sentiment and that is tragic for this country. It really is tragic domestically and internationally. I remember when I was Minister coming across examples of racism but always seeing many more examples of the compassion of which the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has spoken. I agree with him. I recall that when anti-Asian slogans were being painted on bus shelters in Perth people of British origin and very conservative outlooks on life went out at midnight in their pyjamas and dressing gowns and painted out those slogans. They would not write letters to the paper but they just did not want racism. I remember that when a Vietnamese barber was sacked because a customer would not have his hair cut by him my Department and the Courier-Mail were inundated with people wanting to employ him. That led to the employment of a lot of other Vietnamese.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who helped to keep the lid on? It was this Party.

—Absolutely. Let me say in response to the Minister that not only do we not deny it but also, prior to the Minister coming to the chamber, I praised the previous Opposition, the honourable member for Port Adelaide who was the previous shadow Minister, and the Prime Minister in his absence. I do so unstintingly because we have been at one on this. There has not been a conspiracy of silence. We have had maturity and statesmanship. We just are disturbed that by clamping down to a greater degree than the market demanded on the occupational categories--
—That is not what they have been saying.

—I ask the Minister to listen to me. There is one more thing I must say. The Australian Bureau of Statistics's category of Asians includes people from Lebanon and the Middle East. Let us remember that too. Again there is a distortion even in the figures that are used and I hope that the Statistician might give thought to using the figures more accurately in terms of country of origin. I made it quite clear that we remain committed to the policies which we were committed to before. We just wish that in the administration of the program the Government would in fact return to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I share the views of the Foreign Minister and, I believe, those of the Prime Minister, and the honourable member for Warringah, in saying that we really do need a higher migrant intake in this country. I know that this becomes an act of faith because one cannot really demonstrate it to everyone's satisfaction. I commissioned an inquiry on the economics of migration which I think is going to report soon to the Government. I believe that part of the special relationship which the Government has with the trade union movement could be used to allay the understandable but nonetheless misplaced fears of those who are looking for employment that they will not be employed if there is an increase in migration. On the contrary, all the evidence is that migration creates a demand for goods and services which will actually create more jobs. Certainly, bringing in retirees with income and capital to invest, who will not be drains on our social security system, as well as business migration in particular are amongst those things which will create new jobs.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) have spoken several times about their approach to training and to the intake of skilled migrants. I see no evidence of any progress being made in respect of adult apprenticeship and other training programs. So the result will be that when the economy begins to grow again we will have to import more skilled migrants again. It is sad that we have not gone into the upgrading of the skills of many of our own people. As a result this situation will happen again. It is a cyclical factor so there are other things that need looking at.

I believe that, if there has been a drop in the number of applications from the United Kingdom and Europe, the Minister has an obligation to put the figures on the table. He has not done so. I have not seen the figures. The Minister, in his contribution today-though I congratulate him on his measured tone and great control after the emotion which preceded his speech-still did not put down the figures on the drop in applications and in successful people. Until he does that there will be the suspicion that the Government is in fact being discriminatory in its approach. I do not believe it is. I do not believe that the Government has been discriminatory. I accept the Minister's words. I know the Prime Minister too well to believe that he would preside over a government which was racist and which discriminated against Caucasians or anyone else. I know that is true. But until the Minister explains himself and satisfies those who are expressing this concern, the concern will linger and, for as long as it lingers, it is fodder for the racists. I believe, as the honourable member for Warringah said, we are not only a nation of immigrants but also we have always been multicultural and we are predominantly tolerant. I think it is a good thing that this debate has come out into the open. However, it will be much better if the Minister can put on the table the facts that support his position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quite deliberately have not listened, apart from the last few minutes of the speech made by my friend, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), to the previous contributions to this debate, nor have I come into the chamber with a prepared speech because, as Prime Minister, I wish to make a statement in this House which I hope will go to fundamental issues in regard to which we can achieve bipartisanship in this House and a very large measure of agreement in the Australian community. Perhaps by way of introduction to the things I would like to say I could quote very briefly from a speech that I was able to make a few days ago on 26 April when the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia invited me to be the guest speaker at its function. I said there by way of opening, and I would like to repeat it here:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not bring to your areas of interest some concern recently acquired as Prime Minister of Australia. For from my earliest time of contemplation about our great country I have perceived much of that greatness, and potential for greatness to be associated with our readiness to open up our land to those who would join us from other countries.

In joining the Australian Labor Party in my first year at the University of W.A . in 1947, and in establishing the first branch of the Party there in 1948, one of the reasons was a sense of excitement and identification with the vast immigration program then being initiated by the great Labor Governments of the war and immediate post-war periods. In my way, then, I attempted to play some part in this opening up process by establishing also the Australian-Overseas Students Club at the University to bring closer together those from diverse national backgrounds.

And as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the decade of the 1970s, I participated fully with the Governments of both political persuasions in their work dealing with immigration policies and programs.
And so I stand before you tonight--
I was able to say to them--
proudly, as one with almost forty years of commitment to, and action in support of those concepts and issues which are so important to all of you.

What I said on 26 April at the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council was a direct and truthful statement of the long-standing involvement, concern and commitment that I have in this area. Indeed, it was a matter of great excitement to me, as a young Australian in that immediate post-war period, to be associated , as a member of the Labor Party, with the vastly imaginative program that was initiated at that time. I saw it as a mark of the vision of the members of my Party that while they had the responsibility of saving this country in the time of war they were, in those very darkest hours, addressing their minds to gathering around them some of the best minds and intellects in this country to think about what sort of Australia we would have in the post-war period.

We all know the great success of that program. We started immediately at the conclusion of the war the greatest recorded migration program in history. That has meant that as of this night almost 40 per cent of the people living in this country today were either born in another country or are the children of a parent born in another country. Indeed, the 1981 census shows that the people of this country are made up of people who have come from over 92 countries of origin. We have moved from being a country of seven million people at the end of the last war to a country now of over 15 million people. We are truly a global country.

I also recall quite clearly that when that program was being initiated there was unfortunately, but perhaps understandably, prejudice against many of those immigrants to Australia. All honourable members who are old enough to remember will recall some of the nastiness, unpleasantness and disasters in many areas of human relations that were associated in those early days with the undertaking of the program which so changed this country. No one will be able to measure how much a greater and better country Australia is because that program has meant that, as of tonight, almost 40 per cent of people living in this country were either born in another country or are children of a parent born in another country. We are a greater, richer and better country because of what has happened.

I recall that in those early days, as people were being gradually confronted by the processes of change, there were many incidents that were unpleasant and tragic in many ways. I had hoped that we had learned from that experience. I pay great credit to the Liberal Party and the Country Party of that period, which were in opposition, that they associated themselves with the great immigration program that was initiated by the Labor governments of that period because they could see what it meant for this country. From the time of the change of government in 1949 there was a bipartisanship, essentially, about this great program which saw our great material resources and our great opportunities and capacities develop more effectively because we were enriched and enlarged by this greatly diverse flow of people from so many different countries of origin.

It is a matter of record now, acknowledged not only in this country but also around the world, just what a magnificent contribution Australia made then. Let us be quite clear that there were two elements to it. We made the decisions at that time, as a country, to enlarge our population by this immigration program because we could see that it would be good for Australia, as indeed it has been. However, we sell ourselves short if we do not also acknowledge at a time like this that there was a great humanitarian element in that program because we were witnessing a world which had been devastated in war and we knew that we had the opportunity of offering to so many of those tragically devastated people the chance to make a new and better life with us. So those two considerations operated together-considerations of the interests of this country and also a commitment to doing what we could to help those less fortunate than ourselves who sought a new life with us.

I believe that it is very unfortunate that we have recently witnessed again-I am not saying this in a partisan sense; it has happened within the community and I am not referring to events of recent days or of today-some greater manifestation of prejudice in this country against immigrants, perhaps in general but more particularly against those who have come to us from Asian countries. I want to say as Prime Minister and as leader of the Government and of my Party that we unequivocally set our face against those elements in our community. While I lead this Party we will never seek to gain any political advantage from paying any sort of notice to, or in any way encouraging, those elements within our community which operate in that way.

It is important that we understand just what has happened in our country over recent years in respect of the major source of Asian immigration. Following the end of war in Vietnam the then Government, with the full support of the Labor Opposition, moved to increase the flow of Asian refugees to this country. I have figures which I believe are relevant. There was a significant increase in 1977- 78. In round figures, in 1977-78, 7,000 refugees came from Asian countries, which was an increase from the 1,000 refugees which had come to Australia the year before. The intake figures for the following years are as follows: In 1978- 79, there were 12,000 refugees; 1979-80, 15,000; 1980-81, 16,000; and in 1981-82 , 15,000. The figure went down to 13,000 in 1982-83 and in 1983-84 there will be an intake estimated at 10,000 refugees.

Governments of that period, the previous conservative coalition and this Government, recognised that this country has a responsibility to provide a home for those refugees from the tragic conflicts of Indo-China. That has been, and I hope will remain, a bipartisan approach. The Government, having made a decision in regard to the overall level of immigration on economic grounds, which this Government did by reducing the gross intake in 1983-84 to 70,000 from the 93,000 of the previous year, remains committed to the rights of those who are already here to partake in that element of the program of family reunion. Inevitably and statistically that has meant there must be a change in the composition, in terms of ethnic origin, of those who come into this country. That is precisely what has happened because those tens of thousands of refugees have come in here in the last few years, the numbers of which I have given. They have exercised their rights of family reunion under our program and so there has been some upward movement in the proportion of people of Asian origin.

I simply say, in respect of the attitude of this Government to refugees and immigration, that when we come to make the decision for the next year on the level of immigration we will make the decision in regard to that absolute level on the criteria that we believe will be in the economic interests of this country. In making that decision, we will not then artificially say that we have to boost some particular area so that we counterbalance some element that has come in from the Asian region. That is not the way with decency and responsibility that one goes about undertaking an immigration program. This Government will not do that. What we will do is determine what we believe the interests of this country require in economic terms as an absolute level. Having done that, we will not deny to any person or group living in Australia the right to family reunion. There are not first and second class citizens in this country in respect of rights to family reunion, and there will never be under this Government. We will not directly or indirectly adopt any course of action which explicitly or implicitly suggests that there are second class citizens.

Directing myself quite specifically to that element of prejudice which does exist within our community against people who have come into our country from Asia, I ask, indeed plead with, my fellow Australians to look at this issue objectively. It just occurred to me before I came into the chamber that perhaps one way we could best look at this is to remember a matter which has been very much before Australian eyes in recent times. I refer to what is happening in one of the major hospitals in Sydney, the greatest city in this country. In that city of Sydney at the moment a magnificent fight is being waged. (Extension of time granted).

I refer to the fact that at this time in Sydney a magnificent fight is being waged to save the life of a young Australian, Fiona. I ask Australians to remember who is leading that fight to save her life. It is a Dr Chang. I do not know the antecedents of Dr Chang but I am sure it was not Gundagai or Tallarook; it was somewhere in Asia. Dr Chang has already saved the lives of some Australians. He has saved the life of an Australian shearer. I do not think that that shearer or anyone associated with him, or any of our fellow Australians who share the joy of what has been happening, suggest that we are not enriched as a country and improved because we have Dr Chang there doing what he is doing, leading the fight at the moment to save the life of Fiona.

Once Australians understand that these are human beings whom we are talking about, people who share the same sorts of aspirations and hopes for themselves and their families as we do, I do not believe that we should begin to allow to creep into our society any element of anti-Asianism. I find it repugnant to the way in which this country developed. We have developed as a great country because we have seen that, by taking people from other countries and by eliminating from our program any concept of prejudice, we can be a strong and better country and we can do those things for others less fortunate than ourselves that we should do.

I also make the point that I have made in other more obviously economic contexts. There are very few things that one can be certain of in life when we are talking in the field of economics. But there is one thing that we can be certain of when we are talking about the economic future of this country; that is, that the future wellbeing, the future development, the future capacity for growth, the future capacity for improving living standards in this country, is to be seen in terms of the fact that we must become and we will inevitably become more enmeshed in the region of which we are a part. We are a country of just over 15 million people in a world of seven and a half billion, but in a region of billions of people. We have to understand as Australians that that is where our future lies. It is where our capacity to provide a better life for our children and their children lies. Therefore, anything that this country does which is in fact or which is seen to be in terms of prejudice against that region would be not only immoral but also manifestly against the present and future best interests of the people of this country.

I think it can be seen from the contribution that I have made that I am not seeking to score political points on this. I am not trying to advance the interests of this Government against the Opposition. What I am trying to say to this House and to all people on whatever side of the chamber is that they please ensure that what we do as members of this Parliament involves the recognition of the truth of which I have been speaking. We should try together to set an example to the people of this country, recognising that tendencies exist in some areas for prejudice against immigrants, perhaps generally and Asians in particular; we should try to accept our responsibilities to ensure that, as far as we can, we eliminate those prejudices and together act in a way to ensure within this country a more cohesive community and, in terms of our relations with our Asian neighbours, a more acceptable face and image. If the Opposition wants to have discussion or debate about the absolute levels of immigration and what on economic grounds those levels should be, of course that is a totally appropriate debate and we welcome it. But we do not welcome, either in this place or outside it, anything which goes to the question of prejudice or intolerance towards any ethnic group.

I conclude by saying that, while there have been some unfortunate events very recently, I take some hope and comfort from this debate and I hope that it will point the way not only to this House but also to the country and ensure that from this day on we as a Parliament will be seen to be doing all that we can in accepting our responsibility to eliminate prejudice in this country and to see that positively we do all that we can to ensure that we are a more cohesive and stronger community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I naturally agree with the sentiments that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) expressed a moment ago throughout his speech. They are sentiments that would be endorsed by members on this side of the House. I make the point, however, and not as a political point to be played up but as a point that I feel impelled to make, about the response that was given to the Prime Minister's speech by all members of the Australian Labor Party. I have here from the Library pulls of statements by members opposite accusing members on this side of the House of being racist. I leave the matter there. I do not think it should even be debated in the spirit and the way in which this discussion has occurred. But I will not allow a situation to go by without some complaint when members of my Party or the National Party of Australia have questions to raise on immigration; it ought not be allowed that they be accused in that way. I leave it there.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak with very great feeling on this matter, as did the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). I have previously spoken volumes in support of the Special Minister of State. I know what he went through. I, as Foreign Minister, with successive immigration Ministers, was trying to get the Australian community to accept the significant increase in Indo-Chinese refugees . It was an extraordinarily sensitive time for any of us who were actively involved in this area. It was not just Ministers; shadow Ministers and leaders of the Party as well had to contend not only with the broader community but also with pressures and concerns that expressed themselves in both major political parties. Heavens above, it is only 22-odd years ago that both major parties were being pushed, properly so, to abandon the White Australia policy. It is as recent as that. As a student, I participated in those campaigns. It was not until Harold Holt became Prime Minister that we effectively put it behind us. The Australian Labor Party got rid of it from its platform some years before. So there is an enormous amount of bipartisan spirit in this House on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for your shadow Minister.

—I will not accept that. I accept what the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said. In my view, our record in regard to immigration in this nation, other than the element I referred to in regard to the White Australia policy, has been unassailable. I reiterate that I know how difficult it was for honourable members opposite when they were on our side of the House to give support to that policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view there are two essential elements to be addressed in a migration policy such as this if we are truly to carry the community with us. We have to recognise the fragility of the concept of community acceptance. Those elements are the people who come here, and the great contributions they make, and the people who were already here. The main charge we have made against the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) is that an imbalance has occurred over the last 12 months. He denies it; we affirm it. And I affirm the right of my members to say they want a bipartisan approach. If there is a change, as we believe there has been-and the figures from the Minister's Department support that-then we have every right to ask him why. He has every right to give those reasons. If the reason is that he wants the Indo-Chinese who came here in the last seven or eight years to be able to live with their families, he should say so. But he should add to it the Prime Minister's view that there are no first and second class citizens; that if in fact they have that right, so too do other , perhaps European, migrants. That is why we moved the amendment calling for a return to a proper, balanced and rational immigration policy for Australia.

The magnitude of the disaster for our community if the Government gets too far out in front of this issue cannot be understated. I know, as honourable members opposite know, that leadership on social issues involves getting out and selling it to people. But this is such a fragile concept that if the Government rushes the matter too much or does not explain the change it risks losing that degree of community support that has developed over the last seven or eight years or the last decade. The Australia we want is a united Australia. I know members of the Government want that and I know we want that, but the Government will place that in jeopardy if it does not indicate to people why it is making these changes.

These changes are truly evident when we look at the applications. The Minister says that there has been a diminution, a drop, in applications from Europe for migration to Australia under the family reunion program. The figures of his Department do not support that. They show that in all countries in Europe bar the Netherlands there has been an increase in the number wishing to come to this country. It is simply not true that there has been a drop in interest or desire by Europeans to come to this country. Therefore we say to the House that if there has been this change, as evinced by the figures, we want the Minister to explain why.

TALK.START.PARA: —But explain what you say we have done wrong and what you would do.
—I will say what the Government has done wrong. It went into an election campaign with its shadow Minister endorsing our program.
—But we won.
—Certainly, but I was asked to tell the Government what it did wrong and I will do it. The Minister indicated--
—Get to the specifics.
—I did not interrupt the Prime Minister when he was not giving any specifics on this issue.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—The Minister has to explain why the imbalance has occurred and what he is prepared to do to correct it. What he has to do is not reduce the Asian element that is there but redress the imbalance by increasing the European element that has been allowed to slip as has been evinced by the figures. That is what the Minister has to do. I repeat that one of the hallmarks and the outstanding successes of the Fraser Government under successive Ministers for immigration was our immigration policy. It was totally supported by the Labor Opposition.
—You want a quota, do you?

—I do not want a quota. The Government should fix a figure and work with it. The honourable member for Robertson should not give me that specious talk about racism on this side and interject on me. I regard this matter as one of great sensitivity. Clearly some government members do not. I said that I would not pursue what is in these pulls of Hansard and the remarks that some Government members have made. They should not accuse any member of my Party of fuelling this matter when week after week in this Parliament they have made accusations that do not sit with anyone on this side. The most important element is that fragile community standard. If the Government loses sight of it it will create a disaster that will not be desired by any member on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The elements of our successful policy should be understood by the Government. They were a balanced migrant intake, an emphasis on family reunion and refugee settlement and on an increasing recognition that in future more and more immigrants would come from non-European sources. We have said it time and again. But the nub of the matter in seeking bipartisanship is that that community support must not be lost as it has been in record time, a little over 12 months, by this Minister. On several occasions the Minister has justified the intake balance on the ground that there is diminished interest, or words to that effect , in migration to Australia from Europe and the United Kingdom. The figures show that to be false. (Extension of time granted) It is this Minister who, by a very authoritarian mishandling of his responsibilities, by a lack of sensitivity and a lack of frankness to those members in the House who would question him on this matter, has brought about the change in policy. There is a change. I repeat that I will not allow my members to be described as racist when they ask the Minister why this change and this imbalance has occurred.

If the Prime Minister is really serious and not coming in on some emotional issue to talk with the frankness that he did, he will talk with his Minister. He will probably go beyond that in my view and replace him with someone with the necessary sensitivity and understanding that immigration policy and administration require. We must have in mind both the people who want to come to Australia to share in the benefits of living here and the concerns of those who already live here. The key point that the Minister must bear in mind is that departure in certain respects from the bipartisan policy has occurred. It has not occurred as a result of any change in attitude or administration on this side of the House but because of a change in ministerial administration. As a result, the Caucasian component has dropped and the proportion of Asian intake has risen. It has not remained the same; it has risen in relative terms. The Minister should not run away from explaining why that has occurred and he should not indicate with falsity that there has been a lack of interest in the European intake.

The Minister is providing fodder for the active minority of racists in this community. If there has been a downturn in applications from Europe, the Government has to prove it. I believe that the figures show that there has been no downturn. Unless the Minister approaches this matter in the responsible manner adopted by the Special Minister of State and by the Prime Minister-I regret though that he did not address the particular issue, although he spoke movingly-we will have to go on questioning the Government as to why this change has occurred.

I conclude on the following note: We are all united in wanting to see a strong migration program continue in this country. We want to see that those from the Asian-Pacific region with whom we trade, mix and travel, have access to this country. But we also want to see that the European nature of this nation continues in the sense that there is a balance in the migration intake. I know that I speak for the vast majority of Australians when I affirm that. When the Minister says that he is not pro-Asianisation he is saying it not because we have raised it but because, firstly, some of his own people have said that has to be his policy and, secondly, his current figures give weight to that being a trend. If that is the case, I will not allow on behalf of the Opposition parties a call for bipartisanship to override the right of any honourable member on this side of the House to call into question justifiably the administration of this portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the national technology strategy discussion draft paper. I seek leave to make a statement in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The national technology strategy discussion draft evolved from the first National Technology Conference held in Canberra from 26 to 28 September 1983, opened by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and attended by 140 representatives of Commonwealth, State and territorial governments, the research and academic communities, industry, finance, service providers and the trade unions. At that conference an undertaking was given that a draft technology strategy would be circulated to participants and made available for public discussion before being submitted to government for adoption and action. This discussion draft fulfils that undertaking. Technology is to be understood in this document as it was defined by the National Academy of Science in the United States:

SPEECH.PARA: Technology is a perishable resource comprising knowledge, skills and the means of using and controlling factors of production for the purpose of producing, delivering to users, and maintaining goods and services for which there is an economic and/or social demand.

In summary on page 1, the following five national priorities are set out as matters for debate. The strong language used is intended to make sure that the sleepers do actually wake. Many will argue about some of the specific figures in the text. These are by way of illustration only. Some will feel, for example, that the figures about the number of students who should complete secondary education and go on to tertiary education by 1995 are too high, others that they are too low. The use of target dates and figures in the document should not be seen as a pre-empting of a final decision by Government and the community -they are merely a starting point for what should be a lively public debate, and it was thought preferable to use specific, quantified examples rather than retreating into vague verbal formulas. These are the five points:

1. Raising Australia's skill base. Our future development depends on knowledge- intensive industries. Our numbers completing secondary education and entering tertiary education are low compared with many Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries, and have fallen far behind Japan and Korea in our region. This should lead to a commitment to:
50 per cent of students completing secondary school by 1995;
20 per cent of school-leavers entering tertiary education by 1995;
retraining at least one per cent of the work force each year.
2. Bridging the gap between research and industry through, for example:
1.5 per cent of gross domestic product to be spent on research and development by 1990, 2 per cent by 1995;
major increase in private sector research and development, reversing the brain drain;
improved overseas and local science and technology information gathering and dissemination;
encouraging personal interaction;
portable superannuation.
3. Moving the Australian economy away from high bulk low value added exports towards high value added goods and services, with high unit value and low volume , making use of:
application of key technologies-for example, biotechnology, microelectronics;
research, invention and design skills.
4. Creating stronger and more appropriate economic structures capable of identifying market niches, providing goods which can be placed on a world market . This will involve:
a more sophisticated approach to marketing;
raising adequate capital;
attracting talent;
exploring point ventures with overseas outlets.
5. Overcoming the problems of overspecialised regional economies such as in coal, steel and heavy manufacturing areas:
diversification and economic recovery in areas where the traditional employment bases are changing rapidly.

A national technology strategy has to answer this question for Australia: Can a nation with only 15 million people, a mere 4 per cent of the English speaking world, with a federal system of government and with a long tradition of ' truncated development' in industry, assert its technological sovereignty, make a contribution to world technological development and achieve higher national growth rates? I believe the answer is 'Yes', but I do not underestimate the difficulties. Australia is starting far behind. I have adopted from Canada the useful term 'truncated development' to describe a superficial form of industrialisation where subsidiaries do not carry out all the functions, from original research to marketing, necessary for developing, producing and selling goods and where foreign factors of production-capital, technology and management -largely substitute for local ones. This has been a major disincentive for large corporations domiciled in Australia to seek to be internationally competitive. They are not programmed to do it, with very rare exceptions such as General Motors' Camira. Tables for trade in technology-based product groups by the 24 nations of the OECD in 1980 illustrate Australia's poor position very clearly. I seek leave to have the two tables incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Honourable members will note that the Federal Republic of Germany ranked first in 1980 in dollar value of technology-based exports with $73.6 billion or 19.6 per cent of the total, the United States of America was second with 18.8 per cent and Japan was third with 13 per cent. Australia ranked nineteenth with 0.3 per cent. It should also be noted that many of the countries with the largest per capita exports in high technology have smaller populations than Australia. In 1980 our figure was $81 per head. Switzerland's was $2,584, 32 times higher; the Netherlands' was $1,378, 17 times higher; Sweden's, $1,087, 13 times higher; and Canada's $340, 4 times higher. Australia ranked twentieth of 24 nations per capita. That was the bad news. The good news is that we are still ahead of Portugal, Greece, Iceland and Turkey.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that we recognise, and counteract, the cultural limitations of our technology base. The Dutch and the Swedes make an important contribution partly because each generation is under a strong cultural imperative to leave its mark on the world. Here we see ourselves as a mere branch office of the English speaking world. We live in a technological culture which is essentially derivative. We buy ideas and products off the shelf and pay for them in raw materials. To many Australians the idea that we should not try to reinvent the wheel is regarded as a profound observation. In fact it begs the whole question of what inventiveness, product and process innovation involve.

Australia's poor performance in applied technology is particularly deplorable because of our high performance in pure research. With only 0.3 per cent of the world's population we produce about 2.0 per cent of the world's scientific papers each year, placing us in the top 10 nations-eighth in the OECD-behind Canada, but well ahead of Switzerland, the Netherlands and Sweden. The survey published last week by PA Technology Australia drew attention to our ranking as No. 20 in an innovative technology index by the European Management Forum at Davos, Switzerland. Oddly, our poor performance is linked with an unusually high degree of managerial complacency. Seventy-one per cent of senior executives interviewed for the survey thought that new technology had either a 'great deal' or a 'fair amount' of impact on their companies' products over the last four to five years.

As the recent OECD Science and Technology Indicators pointed out, there is a disturbing imbalance in Australian spending on research and development. Only 19 .7 per cent comes from the private sector and 77.6 per cent from government sources, a ratio of 1 : 4. In Switzerland the private sector contributes 73.8 per cent, government 17.4 per cent-4 : 1, an exact reversal of our situation. In aiming for an overall doubling of expenditure in research and development by 1995 we should require the private sector to increase its share rapidly, to at least 33 per cent by 1990-91 and 50 per cent by 1995-96.

We have talked a great deal on the past about R and D-research and development- which has meant in practice big 'R' Research and little 'd' development. If we are to recognise and take advantage of dramatic changes in world trade, as recent research papers by the Department of Trade point out, rather than retreating from it and suffering the consequences, we shall have to talk not just of R and D, but R, D, Q and M-research, development, quality control and marketing. In many ways points 3 and 4 of the proposed national priorities raise the most serious challenge for us. We have concentrated almost exclusively on the export of high bulk low value added commodities. We measure the value of our exports in tonnes-our contemporaries measure theirs in grams.

There are stong resemblances between the Canadian and Australian economies: Both of us are immensely resource rich, but with the commanding heights of the economy in foreign hands, manufacturing in long term decline, a reduced share of world markets and a sense of frustration about failure to match rates of growth in newly developing countries. However, in the past few years the Canadians have put a heavy emphasis on focusing their efforts in comparatively few areas, applying the niche approach with success. They have gained world markets with telecommunications equipment, specialised computer applications, the Telidon on- line data bank, instrumentation and process controls and some space technology. Bell Canada, Mitel, Northern Telecom, Infomat, Glenayre, Western Research and Bytec-Conterm have internationally recognised brand names. In a recent Fortune survey of the 500 largest industrial corporations outside the United States, Canada had 32, Sweden 20, Switzerland 13, the Netherlands 11, South Korea 9 and Australia 7.

At the Conference strong support was expressed for the development of a national competence in key technologies such as microelectronics and biotechnology 'through education (manpower), financing (venture capital), management advice and marketing information; and support for new firms in, for example, the sunrise industries'. This ran contrary to the strongly expressed view in parts of the bureaucracy and the financial Press that 'you cannot pick winners', an assertion which has the status of a religious dogma. It is not clear who said it first, and with what authority, but the phrase is often invoked in Canberra as if it were self-evident and required no supporting evidence. The phrase can mean many things. Few would disagree if it is used to mean that the actual performance in the market of particular companies is highly unpredictable and subject to chance factors. At the other extreme it becomes an expression of economic agnosticism-that it is not possible to use knowledge to make judgments based on general trends as if nobody could say with confidence that microelectronics or biotechnology will have greater growth prospects than sausage casings or raincoats. The Conference rejected the latter view and so do I.

We lack an inventory of finished products suitable for overseas marketing and have few overseas outlets which could back up a successful marketing strategy which could place goods and back up services close to consumers throughout the world. It is in this area that Sweden, with only 8.3 million people, has been outstandingly successful. The Yellow Pages indicate that Volvo and Saab-Scania have 23 authorised outlets for sales and services in Sydney, 15 in Melbourne, 10 in Brisbane, 6 in Adelaide and 5 in Perth. It would be fair to say that an aspiring purchaser of an Australian designed and manufactured car would have his work cut out if he was looking for one in Stockholm or Uppsala.

There are many Australian outlets for Electrolux, SKF, ASEA, L.M. Ericsson, Bofors, Hasselblad, Husqvarna and Atlas Copco. There is no equivalent penetration of Swedish markets or consciousness by Australian brand name goods. It is not that we have a poor reputation-we simply have no reputation at all except in some areas of componentry. We must overcome the essential fragility of our industrial infrastructure. The Conference must be taken as the starting point of an important process. Many conclusions are tentative because the participants barely knew each other. It is essential that the debate be continued and widened and it is on this basis that I commend the paper to the House and the public.
