SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am responding to the statement made by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) on the national technology strategy. In so replying, I am speaking in place of the shadow Minister for Science and Technology, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who is overseas on business connected with his shadow portfolio. The Minister's response to the national technology strategy is unsatisfactory, for it provides no answers and announces no decisions. It is very disappointing for the application of new technologies in industries in Australia. It is very disappointing for business in Australia. The Minister keeps talking about the application of new technology but he has achieved very little or nothing at all. The Minister is constantly getting publicity about science and technology. He talks about new technologies, but we have no practical policies put in place by this Government. This statement on the national technology strategy, made by the Minister to the House today, announces no new policies and no decisions.
—It is a discussion draft.
—The Minister admits it is a discussion draft.
—I do not admit it; I assert that it is a discussion draft.

—The Minister asserts it. I am saying that the Minister's assertion that it is a discussion draft is no answer from a Minister of the Crown in this country who has been a Minister for over a year. He should have more than a discussion draft on the subject of the national technology strategy. That is the very point I make. The Government has made no decisions. The Minister's statement is just a repetition of very similar and familiar rhetoric that we have heard from the Minister. Let me look particularly at the Minister's statement. He repeats the five national priorities in the national technology strategy. I suppose it is useful to have them repeated in Hansard. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The strong language used is intended to make sure that the sleepers do actually wake.
I note that the Minister is the author of a book on this subject, called Sleepers, Wake! which is worth reading. I certainly acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —A best seller.

—I hope the Leader of the House has at least bought a copy and not read the Parliamentary Library copy. The book is called Sleepers, Wake! I want to know what we will do when we wake up because the Minister has not told us what we are to do when the sleepers awake.
—We will re-elect the Hawke Government for a start.

—I say to my dear friend, the Minister, judging by the way he is going about this subject, if he does not wake up he will not have any policies in place. His party will be thrown out at the next election. That is the point I am making. The people will wake up to the Government, and that is what will happen when the sleepers awake.

—I will look at the contract, but the Minister should not preach it in such terms. Maybe it is the fault of the CSIRO that it has not worked well enough with industry, but I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: I will look once again at the Minister's statement. He said that we must recognise the cultural limitations of our technology base. That is almost a statement of cultural cringe, because he says:
We live in a technological culture which is essentially derivative . . .

I think that is a very defensive statement, because we have great industries in Australia. We have great primary industry, great rural industry, great mining industry and there is inventiveness and processes of innovation in this country. There is agreement between the Government and the Opposition that there is not enough. I agree that Australia's poor performance in applied technology to which the Minister referred is deplorable, because we have had a high performance in pure research. I agree with him in that case. I think this is one of the matters that need closer examination because if we look at the technology gap between our high performance in pure research and our failure to apply that research in Australian companies involved in the market-place in the development of our science and technology and if we look at the efforts of our scientists in relation to that gap and in analysing reasons for that gap, we will find the answer to the question of what is wrong with the transfer of technology and know -how from scientists in Australia to businesses in Australia. That is a serious question which I exhort the Minister to examine.

The Minister said that there is a disturbing imbalance in Australia's spending on research and development-19.7 per cent comes from the private sector and 77.6 per cent from government sources. What we have to do is look at the reasons for that gap and do something about those reasons. Just at a first blush, if one says that 77.6 per cent comes from government sources and 19.7 per cent comes from the private sector, a general argument can be that in fact the private sector is being crowded out by the public sector. But that is a simplistic argument and I do not necessarily rest on it. I will talk about that gap shortly . The Minister in his statement on the national technology strategy said that we have concentrated almost exclusively on the export of high bulk low value added commodities. I say: What is wrong with that, what is wrong with the great rural industries, what is wrong with using new technologies such as plant variety rights for the great crops of Australia such as wheat and the great animal husbandry industries such as sheep and meat? The Minister says:
We measure the value of our exports in tonnes-our contemporaries measure theirs in grammes.
That is too simplistic. I would like to see both, and I hope that the Minister would agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure.

—I am glad that he agrees. But there has been added value to, as he says, our low value, high bulk commodity industries. There has been development. Look at gold processing; look at the aluminium industry. Value is being added. We have an integrated-
—Pity there is a glut of aluminium.

—Yes, it is a pity that there is a glut of aluminium. But look at commodity prices. If one looks at the recovery that is occurring in the United States of America I predict one will see some growth in market forces. But that is another argument which is not relevant to the fact that in fact added value has been added to processing in Australia. At the moment the market may be down; tomorrow it may be up. That is for the market place. The Minister in his statement talks about picking winners. I ask him what he means by picking winners for new technology in Australia? What are his policies in relation to what he states is his preference for picking winners? I think he owes the House an answer in relation to this. The Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Conference must be taken as the starting point of an important process. Many conclusions are tentative because the participants barely knew each other. It is essential that the debate be continued an widened . . .

I agree that the debate is valuable and I hope it is continued and widened, as the Minister says. But I would like some answers in relation to the questions that relate to the national technology strategy. I think, as I said earlier in the debate-in the time remaining to me I will examine this matter-that an analysis has to be made and an examination undertaken of the reasons for the poor transfer of technology in Australia. I said that part of the reason for this related perhaps to the fact that far too much of the research was done in the public sector and far too little in the private sector. I said that was simplistic.

Let us look at some of the reasons, or the potential reasons, for this poor technology transfer. I said yesterday in the debate on the Patents Amendment Bill 1984 that Australian scientists tend to measure their careers by the number of papers published in international journals. In fact, there is a rush to publish. The scientists of Australia may in fact be doing a disservice not only to themselves but also to Australia generally and to industry in particular because in publishing the results of their initial research, which should have been protected in some way by either being kept secret or by being patented, results are given away to the world via publication and then some other country or some other corporation somewhere in the world sees this great Australian invention and grabs it for itself. I think Australian scientists perhaps ought to examine the role that they play in this poor transfer of technology from the laboratories, the universities and the research institutions to the businesses, the companies, the firms and the corporations of Australia where the profits are made. That is one point I would like to look at in relation to the poor transfer of technology.

The second reason may relate to the whole history of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation itself as well as to other institutions. For example, researchers at the Australian National University, the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research and the CSIRO have recently announced with some pride that United States companies have brought certain development rights. I referred to one of those earlier in the debate and the Minister and I had some discussion about that. The CSIRO made another statement that it had entered into an Agreement with an overseas corporation in relation to jumping genes in the area of biotechnology for the development of maize. That is something which I think bears looking into. We need to establish why these great institutions in Australia announce with pride that some of their discoveries will be developed overseas.

I think one cannot underestimate the fact that science and industry people in industries do not seem to mix well in Australia and this is shown by a number of indicators. Most doctors of philosophy in this country tend to stay in the university or CSIRO environment rather than being found in industry. Perhaps scientists, like some of their British counterparts, traditionally have a very reserved attitude at the least towards the so-called merchant class people of commerce. I think that is a tragedy. I think there needs to be more co-operation between the universities, CSIRO, other institutions and the business sector. If that does not happen we are going to miss out altogether.

I think, as I said earlier, the history of the CSIRO has to be looked at. Perhaps the organisation is far too idealistic and non-commercial. I recognise that the CSIRO in recent years has tried to respond adequately to social and political pressures-not bad political pressures but political pressures all the same-to make it take more account of the market place. I hope it is not a matter of too little too late. For instance, recent efforts have been made to get the CSIRO interested in manufacturing. Under the former Government a new division of the CSIRO was created. I think that another reason for the poor technology transfer is that public libraries have been poorly funded and do not have a strong technological emphasis. I think that much more has to be done in this age of the computer to transfer technology from the laboratory to the business. I think, in looking at the Minister's statement on the national technology strategy, there needs to be a greater dialogue between industry and scientists. Ways need to be developed for the transfer of technology to the private sector so that technology, ideas and developments can commercially be exploited by businesses small and large in Australia.

I conclude by saying that I think the Minister's response is disappointing and unsatisfactory and does nothing to solve the problems of technology transfer from science and the scientific institutions of Australia to the companies, businesses, firms and corporations in Australia. The Minister provides no answers to the difficulties.

The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mrs Child and Mr Coleman.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition for the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth: That Regulations and an Ordinance now before the parliament amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs ( Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law:
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr,Mr Goodluck and Mr Newman.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to reaffirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown and Mr Cadman.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Dobie.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control.
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: May it please you to accept the humble petitions of the undersigned citizens of Australia.

The petitions of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that:
''the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of Society and is entitled to the protection by society and the state''.
And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above article 23 (1) .
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implication would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c) being of disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to Mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the Convention is likely to result in Maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further Marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
We, as members of a school Parents' Club, object to legislation that calls for the payment of the Bank Debit Tax by a voluntary organisation working for the benefit of children in government schools.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that-
Exemption from the payment of Bank Debit Tax will be granted to School Parents' Clubs in government schools
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements, and;
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation, presently under re- examination, is iniquitous and if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Government to:
1. totally abandon its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter, and;
3. following the report of such wide enquiry, institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non- discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of Medicare has not resulted in a cheaper, fairer system of health care as promised by the Federal Government.
Rather, it is an expensive, bureaucratic scheme, depersonalising medical services and conducive to medical mediocrity.
While recognising the responsibility which exists to assist those in need, we humbly request the Government to review this system which moves towards the nationalisation of Australian medicine.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows their concern for the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium, the development of nuclear power and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will
1. prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.
2. declare a moratorium on all mining and treatment of Uranium in Australia.
3. prohibit the export of Australian uranium.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Patersons Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Patersons Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Forrest respectfully showeth that the Australian Citizenship Act contains provision for the Oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors, and an Affirmation of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors: That the said Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are supported by the overwhelming majority of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled will ensure that the present Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are retained; and would strongly oppose any attempt to remove all reference to God and the Queen from the Oath of Allegiance, and any attempt to remove all reference to the Queen from the Affirmation of Allegiance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable Member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The rapidly rising community concern about the Hawke Government's divisive handling of Australia's immigration policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
That Government Business be called on.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Patents Amendment Bill is but one tool in the Government's strategy to achieve a higher standard of living for all Australians . When the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) was speaking on the ministerial statement by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones ) headed 'National Technology Strategy-Discussion Draft' he said that there were no answers being given and no decisions being made by the Minister. This Bill is just one practical decision made by the Government. He accused the Minister of not waking up. I realise that this Bill is far from the Minister's greatest achievement, but it is proof that the Minister is alive, active and well and truly working. The honourable member for Higgins, who is the small business spokesperson for the Opposition, was a great pontificator. His Government presided over the greatest increase in small business bankruptcies since the Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's future is tied up with our need to recognise where our resources are and how to get the most from those resources. The Patents Amendment Bill 1984 specifically deals with an important way of getting the most from our resources by ensuring that our country and our people are given the credit as well as the financial reward for their work. What are these resources which we want to use to gain due reward for Australia and Australians? First of all, our people; they are our greatest resource. Until we recognise that we will not get very far. It was good to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today, in his speech on immigration, speak about the great resources in our people which have been changed by immigration. When the Minister introduced the Bill, he spoke of the great resources of the people who are working in research. He said that we have biotechnology researchers who are world leaders in agriculture, plant and animal genetics, microbiology, biochemistry and medical research. He said that we must take advantage of the leads we have.

It is true that we have some great resources in Australia. Of course our people are our main resource. We also have mining and agricultural resources. The wool industry currently earns over $1.5 billion in exports yearly. While we may not be on the sheep's back, if there were any threat to our economy we would be frantically holding on to the sheep's tail. The beef industry is another example . One incidental product of the beef industry, cured hides, alone supplies $8.7m in export earnings. Horticulture, timber, dairying and fishing are all efficient primary industries compared with industries in other countries. Of course, we are proven world leaders in agricultural research associated with those industries.

Our agricultural industries are efficient. However, we know that primary production fluctuates. For example, the drought had a devastating effect on primary production. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that a quarter of the economic recovery will be attributable to recovery from the drought. Overall, we have done quite well over the years out of our non-human resources. However, we need to recognise that we have to get the most out of our people and give the most to our people in return. We need to give our people recognition as our most precious resource. There is a tendency, when we are thinking of secondary industries and our labour forces, to say that we are too far from our markets, labour costs are too high and we have no technological base. It is true that these things have prevented Australia from competing overseas in secondary industries.

Dr D. Harrison of Biotechnology Ltd held a useful science and industry forum at Thredbo recently. He said that high technology provides opportunities to revolutionise secondary industry and provides new opportunities for Australia to compete, especially where manufacturing is based on raw materials. This point is very valid. I mentioned before that our export earnings from the wool crop totalled $1.5 billion. If we converted that wool our income from exports as a result of that conversion would be far higher. Goulburn Wool Processors Pty Ltd is converting wool by using high technology through a computer which has been devised locally by a person employed by Goulburn Wool Processors. This will contribute substantially to the Goulburn economy. If we converted our $1.5 billion wool crop to yarn we could export not $1.5 billion worth of product but $10 billion worth. If we converted that yarn to finished cloth our export earnings could total $200 billion. That would mean we would have over $150 billion more for Australian jobs, for Australian technology and for the Australian people. I mentioned that cured hides to the value of $8.2m are being exported yearly. If we converted those hides to leather we would receive over $1 billion in export earnings for that processed leather. That is about 200 times the earnings we are receiving now for the cured hides.

We have the ability; let us get in and develop our high technology. We can cater for distance with our modern transport and communications systems and by tailoring our products for distant markets. Australia has to develop high technology industries to do that. Australia ought to give more attention to those technologies which relate best to our natural resources. This Bill looks at one necessary component of that challenge, the need for people to feel free to handle the results of their own research and to exploit them. It is important , along with the need for co-operation among academic institutions, individuals and governments, that we consider the need for people who are involved in the development of high technology, including biotechnology, to be protected.

There are three ways of protecting people so that they can feel free to handle the results of their own research and to exploit them. Two of them, copyright law and the trade secret legislation, do provide real difficulties when we are looking at biotechnology. As Professor Whalan of the Australian National University points out, the product of genetic engineering needs to be looked at differently from the trade secrets of Drambuie, Coca-Cola or Kentucky Fried Chicken with its 11 spices and herbs. Patent protection is a better basis than either copyright law or trade secret legislation. After some initial difficulties, in the United States of America in particular, patent protection for the results of biotechnological research does not create real difficulties and the quick advances made in biotechnology, which often means early discarding of ideas, can be catered for in legislation.

This Bill improves the ability of researchers to take advantage of opportunities. It improves the ability of industry to compete and thus export. The Bill increases the likelihood of biotechnological developments which will lead to Australia's making better use of at least two resources which are already here, our people and our natural resources such as wool. We support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to respond to a few of the points made last night by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). The honourable member for Higgins asserted last night that the Fraser Government had been a trendsetter in support of biotechnology and that I and the Australian Labor Party had simply tagged along. An examination of Hansard will reveal the absurdity of that proposition. The honourable member must realise its absurdity and I do not really understand why he raised it. I have been reading about and discussing biotechnology for years. In February 1981 I had the benefit of a long discussion about it with Francis Crick, the father of recombinant DNA research. In 1981 alone I raised the issue of biotechnology in this House by way of speeches, questions or notices of motion on the following dates-25 February, 31 March, 9 April, 29 April, 6 May, 12 May, 14 May, 9 September, 21 October and 29 October-while my predecessor, the Hon. David Thomson, spoke on it only twice, on 9 April and 29 April, in both cases in response to what I had said.

SPEECH.PARA: As an illustration of the previous Government's passionate commitment to and deep knowledge of biotechnology, I draw the attention of the House to a question I asked here on 31 March 1981 which is in Volume 121 of Hansard at page 1091. It read as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government recognises the enormous economic significance of biotechnology which appears likely to be the greatest area of industrial growth in the 1980s. If so, what specific steps is the Government taking to promote biotechnology in Australia and to study the major associated ethical problems, including cloning and aging? Is this another example of a high technology industry where once again Australia has missed the bus? Is the Government aware of the Spinks report in Great Britain and the Pelissolo report in France which raise the subject of biotechnology and the importance of it to modern governments.?

SPEECH.PARA: Malcom Fraser flashed his famous smile, so reminiscent of the silver fittings on a coffin, indicated that he did not know what it meant and invited Doug Anthony, as Minister for Trade and Resources, to answer. He then shrugged that he did not know anything about it either so it was passed on to Sir Phillip Lynch, as Minister for Industry and Commerce, to reply. Hansard records the reply as follows:

Sir PHILLIP LYNCH—I am afraid that the honourable gentleman has the advantage of me. I will certainly seek the latest report which is available from officers of the Department of Science and Technology as to the advantage of the particular discipline to which the honourable gentleman refers. I will provide him with that information as soon as possible.

This exercise raised much hilarity in the House and comment in the media, much of it, I fear, aimed against me because the view was taken by some politicians and journalists that the question was incomprehensible: Who on earth could be expected to know what biotechnology was all about? But events moved so rapidly in 1981 that by November the Government had been forced to call a national conference on biotechnology at the Hyatt Kingsgate Hotel in Sydney-or shamed into it, I should say. By November 1981 nobody was laughing about biotechnology, or professing ignorance.

I take up the specific points that the honourable member for Higgins asked me to respond to. He referred to the 'publish or perish' mentality in the scientific community. There is an element of truth in that. However, I think it is fair to say that in the United States of America and here in Australia there is an evolving commercial or business orientation in the biological sciences. A patent or perish mentality may be going too far but there is room for research scientists to re-assess their attitudes in the national interest as well as in the pure and rarefied interests of academia.

The honourable member made the comment that in Australia there has been almost no public debate on the question of patentability of micro-organisms, as there has been in countries such as the United States. That is not quite true. The point in the United States was that the Supreme Court, when it made the judgment in the Chakrabarty case, changed the law in the United States. There never was a need for such a change in the law here because the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office was always prepared to recognise the patentability of biological processes.

But there has been a debate here. It was covered in a paper at the November 1981 symposium to which the honourable member referred. There were a number of discussions including quite an important one in which Mr Justice Kirby and I participated on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Science Show. The honourable member said that patent law is being questioned, and I think that is correct. It is being questioned in Australia. The International Property Advisory Council review on this very subject is due to be completed in two months. But the review, unlike the illustration that the honourable member for Higgins gave, is not based on the filing of useful patent applications by eccentrics. The review is to be based on economic criteria with a view to furthering the national interest.

He inquired what had happened to the venture capital taxation legislation which is needed and which is supplementary to the matters of investment company legislation already passed by the house. The assistant Treasurer, the honourable member for Adelaide, Mr Hurford, has advised that it is expected that this will be introduced within a few days. The Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board has requested some minor variations to the proposed legislation. I think there are quite cogent reasons for the delay. As engineers say, we are all on the learning curve in this area and the original draft legislation that was proposed for the taxation relief would now, we think, not be adequate.

I can assure honourable members and prospective investors that we anticipate that the legislation will be right on course and, as we always said, provided it is carried before 30 June, it will not change the outcome. There is no question that it will be carried in this session. Of course, the honourable member for Higgins and his associates can do a great deal to expedite its passage and I would like to think that it will go through the House with great celerity.

The honourable member made the comment that a considerable number of legal problems were involved. That is absolutely true. Legal problems will always arise in multi-million dollar businesses. The honourable member said:

It is up to the Federal Government to ensure that simple-looking patent applications by Australian companies do not fail in their intent because of legal loopholes exploited by larger overseas corporations. For instance, at what point should the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office declare that one micro- organism is different from another?

. . . I ask the Minister: Can a competitor gain access to a patented micro- organism according to the Budapest Treaty, alter the genetic material, the DNA, slightly by mutation, and then claim to have developed a new micro-organism?

The answer is yes, assuming that it is a patentable difference. The differences between micro-organisms will be viewed in the same way that we look at differences in other areas of technology. They will be judged in the light of practical reality in the area of technology concerned. If biotechnology scientists can tell the difference, then so will the patent law. More importantly, patent law recognises differences which matter in the market place. Small incremental developments may be more important than large advances, particularly for a small country like Australia. The ability to patent small but important developments is fundamental to the whole idea of patents and to the stimulation of a healthy and competitive industry. But the difference in patents must be a real, practical difference. Colourable imitations will not evade a patent infringement or qualify for a new patent. If a development is patented, that does not affect the original patent right unless of course the development is so significant that the original patent then becomes commercially useless. Patents are intended to stimulate further incremental developments. We should not forget that it may be an Australian innovator who can take advantage of a micro-organism deposit made by an applicant from overseas. I want to refer to one other matter. The honourable member said:

The Government must create a climate for this development to take place and encourage investment by the private sector. It is a tragedy that the malaria vaccine developed in Australia has to be sent overseas for commercialisation due to a lack of the necessary infrastructure and support facilities.

This comment is seriously misleading on two grounds. First of all, the experimentation is not at the vaccine stage yet; the people involved are still carrying out fundamental research. What we have is a library of cloned proteins which look as though they will be susceptible to further development and it is likely that they will turn into a vaccine, but it is not at that stage. The joint venturers are the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, the Queensland Institute of Medical Research, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission and Biotechnology Australia. The joint venturers-subsequent events may disprove this-assert that these four entities between them will have the capacity to carry out the commercial development here, and we certainly hope that that will be the case. The honourable member ought to be aware of that.

In the case of some other collaborative ventures involving biotechnology, it has often been the situation that there has needed to be further development or there has needed to be interaction with somebody else. I do not want to put it crudely but it has been a matter of saying 'you show me yours and I will show you mine'. This could be the case with an Australian participant who has not had the entire range of knowledge in an area but has needed collaboration with somebody else who has a complementary skill. That is a factor. We do not have the luxury of getting these developments, hiding them away in the Fuhrer-bunker and saying: 'Well, in five years time the world will come to us and we will be able to sell on our terms'. It really is very difficult.

The final point I make is that the honourable member for Higgins said rather cynically that if he had a child headed into a new career now he would want him to be a patent lawyer, preferably a biotechnology patent lawyer. I am not sure that that is necessarily the case. One of the great ironies of patent law, which even a committed patent official like the Acting Commissioner of Patents would concede, is that the great Chakrabarty case, which was regarded as a turning point in American legal history-which theoretically it was-in fact did not lead to any commercial exploitation at all. I spoke to some of the proponents of the bug-eating biotechnological development which was to chew up oil slicks and they said they did not go ahead with the original patent because they developed a way of doing it which was superior. I asked whether they patented it and they said: 'No, it was not really worth all the hassle. We decided that the thing that keeps you ahead is simply the fact that you have the highest group of skilled people in a particular area, and you are off and running'. It is a race. It is useless simply to wave a piece of paper saying that you have a legal right to do something if you do not have the skilled personnel. I thank the honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After clause 6, page 4, insert the following new clause:
Application for review
''6A. Section 151 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in paragraph (1) (a) '131,' before '154'.''.
(2) Clause 7, page 5, at the end of proposed section 154A add the following sub -section:
'' '(6) An appeal lies to a prescribed court from a decision of the Commissioner under sub-section (1).'.''.

These amendments do not make an awful lot of sense unless the people listening on their crystal sets have a copy of the parent Act in front of them, the Patents Act of 1952. These two small amendments arise from the eternal vigilance of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. They do not specifically relate to the subject of the Bill. The gist of both provisions is this: New clause 6A amends section 151 of the Patents Act to enable a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision of the Commissioner of Patents under section 131 of the Act. Section 131 relates to the prohibition of publication of information in respect of inventions where, say, the Commissioner may be of the view that information is critical to the defence of the Commonwealth, and from that point of view there should be no publication of it. This proposed section provides for an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if this decision of the Commissioner is thought to be arbitrary or ill- founded.

Proposed sub-section 154A (6) provides for an appeal to a prescribed court against a decision of the Commissioner under proposed sub-section 154A (1).
