DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am responding to the second reading speech of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) in relation to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill 1984. This Bill has two purposes. The first is to amend this Act which was passed in 1981 and determines the amount which is to go to the States for certain purposes as part of their tax sharing grants. The first aspect of this is that there was an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States that certain pathology laboratories run by the Commonwealth would be handed over to State administrations. There was an adjustment to Federal-State finances to take that into account. What has happened since then is that in only one State, that of Western Australia, was the transfer of the relevant pathology laboratory effected. It was actually done during the period of my administration as Minister for Health. But in the other States, because of bureaucratic difficulties and the unwillingness of States to accept the responsibility of running these laboratories, they were not passed over. Thus there is a need to make an adjustment in the opposite direction to make sure that the balance between Federal and State finances is maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a matter of major importance, but I think I ought to say that I took some interest in this matter when I was Minister. It was a bit of a Sir Humphrey operation, I am afraid, in that there was a great deal of bureaucratic resistance to the transfer of these pathology laboratories. As far as I am concerned, the Federal Government should not be involved in the running of services of this kind. The actual delivery of such services, the running of pathology laboratories, should be in the hands of State administrations, fundamentally, because they link in with the State health systems. It is a sensible thing in management terms to do that. I took that view. It was not a matter of major importance, so I did not go to great lengths to implement it. I pursued it as well as I could during that period, but it was resisted on local grounds and by the States and the bureaucracy. In only one case, that in Western Australia, was there a satisfactory agreement to transfer the control of that laboratory. I think it is a pity, but it has been acknowledged, presumably, that it is politically difficult to make a sensible managerial decision and so there has been a financial adjustment. That is a relatively minor purpose of this Bill . Of course, the Opposition is not opposing that.

The second purpose of the Bill is to recognise that the general State-Federal financial arrangements are to go to a certain date. The payments under this Act cease on 30 June 1985 and it is provided in the Act that the Commonwealth shall consult with the States to review the provisions of the Act. The States have already been involved in the preparation of the terms of reference under which the Commonwealth Grants Commission can have a look at this situation and at the distribution of tax sharing grants amongst the States. This will be an important input into the negotiation of the new arrangements, but the Commission is not due to report on this matter until 30 March 1985. Since the arrangements cease on 30 June 1985 it is considered sensible by the Government to extend these payments for another six months from 1 July 1985 so that the results of the Grants Commission recommendations can be considered and the Parliament can then decide sensibly on what is to be done. Thus payments may be made during the six months from 1 July 1985, with the amount payable being limited to half the amount being paid to each State in the previous year. If adjustments are to be made as a result of the Grants Commission recommendations they can be so decided . That seems to be a reasonable provision and the Opposition does not offer any objection to that.

Within this relatively technical Bill there are some quite important principles of negotiation between the Commonwealth and States. As might be expected, I have a particular interest in the health grants aspect of that division. I want therefore to make some remarks on the basis of the arrangements betweem the Commonwealth Government and the States with regard to health grants, in particular, to the Medicare arrangements which are part of this legislation. The basis of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the States when Medicare was introduced and as a result of a certain amount of haggling between the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the State Ministers, most of whom were Labor Ministers but that did not stop the degree of haggling because there are substantial differences between Labor Federal Ministers and State Ministers in this area, was that the Commonwealth would pay a substantial sum, in the order of an additional several hundred million dollars of taxpayers' funds, to the States if the States would agree to provide 'free'-I put free in inverted commas because somebody always pays in the end-out-patient services regardless of people's means and also 'free' hospital beds for Medicare patients regardless of the means of those patients. The bed day charges which were to be made to privately insured patients-anybody who was prudent enough to take out private insurance for hospitalisation-were to be reduced from an average of $120 a day for a bed in a public hospital in each of the States down to $80 a day. That was a fairly artificial move, of course, because the average cost of a bed in a public hospital is probably well over $200 a day. The previous actual charge subsidised by the taxpayer was $120 a day. That was reduced to $80 a day for anybody who was privately insured.

There is a tremendous unfairness under the Medicare arrangements to privately insured patients. If somebody who is quite well off has decided not to take out any private hospital insurance, but is subject to the Medicare levy of one per cent of taxable income, and goes along to a public hospital uninsured, that person gets a bed totally free of charge, apart from the Medicare levy paid through taxation. If a person has decided, because he would like the choice of his own doctor, to take out private insurance with a private health insurance fund-that is something that a whole lot of people want to do; people who have been through severe medical problems want the capacity to sack a doctor if he does not do his job properly or to choose the doctor that they want-he will be charged $80 a day for the same public hospital bed which is given free to somebody of possibly equal means who has taken out no private insurance.

We have been told that Medicare is the fairest health insurance scheme that we have ever had in Australia. This provision of Medicare is absolutely and totally unfair. Two people who have exactly the same salaries and expenses can be side by side in the same public hospital and one of them who has done nothing to take out private insurance can get a totally free bed at the taxpayers' expense and the person in the next bed, having prudently taken out private hospital insurance to ensure a choice of doctor, is charged $80 a day for that bed. That is the fairness of Medicare.

Another aspect involving Medicare is that in New South Wales-this is a matter of which I have particular knowledge, since I was defeated in an action before the High Court of Australia on this matter when I was Minister-a levy was imposed by the New South Wales Government for ambulance services. This levy was placed on privately insured patients. Anybody who had insured with a private fund for his medical and hospital care under the previous arrangements had attached to them compulsorily by the New South Wales Government an ambulance levy. That levy was to replace the voluntary insurance program through the ambulance service which previously applied in New South Wales. The then State Minister for Health. Mr Brereton, after this levy had been applied and after I had challenged it in the High Court and lost my case, graciously wrote to all the people in New South Wales who had subscribed to the ambulance service and the fund-I was one of those to whom he wrote-and gave them a cheque for the balance of the year for which they had paid and said that in future they did not have to pay any ambulance levy.

The Federal Minister for Health, under the new Medicare proposals, abolished private health insurance altogether and made it illegal. There was no fund on which to place this parasitic levy by the State Government. The then State Minister for Health, Mr Brereton, had to write, somewhat shamefacedly, to all those people to whom he had written previously and given a cheque to tell them that in future they would have to take out private ambulance insurance. That was one of the outcomes of Medicare. People who were told that they did not have to pay anything found, after Medicare, that they had to take out private ambulance insurance, otherwise they had to pay or $60 or $80 for a trip to a local hospital and considerably more if they were caught with a broken leg up in the snow or whatever and had to be taken to hospital by air ambulance.

There is another major unfairness in the Medicare situation regarding Queensland. Queensland has had a free hospital service for 40 or 50 years. A taxpayer in Queensland has the right to go to a public hospital and have a bed free of charge, regardless of means. Under Medicare he is charged a one per cent levy in order to enjoy the same benefit. The taxpayers of Queensland rightly objected to the fact that they were going to have to pay extra tax to pay for something which they had enjoyed for over 40 years. The Queensland Government objected to this. It received some additional money from the Federal Government but nowhere near enough to compensate for this difference. Eventually it had to bow down to the blackmail of the Federal Government. The Federal Government said : 'If you don't toe the line we will cut off all your money'. Eventually the Queensland Government had no option but to agree, very reluctantly, to the Medicare scheme, which still to this moment robs Quenslanders of a large amount of their tax to pay for things in other States and to pay for a service which they already enjoyed free under the previous situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame! How much is that a head?
—It is worth, I think, about $75m a year to Queenslanders which, spread out among Queenslanders, is a lot of money.
—About $30 a head.
—As my friend the honourable member for Dawson has said, they will be paying $30 a head additional to everybody else in the Commonwealth for a service which they already received free of charge.
—Yes, and we pay the same as everybody else.

—Yes, they pay the same as everybody else, whereas previously they got the service free. They are paying for something which they already had. I think that the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Minister for Health were totally justified in taking the issue to the point where eventually they had to give in because the Federal Government blackmailed them that they would lose all the money if they did not cave in to the dictatorial demands of the Federal Minister for Health.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not only talk about the National Party Premier of Queensland. I refer also to the fact that at the Health Ministers conference, which was assembled to discuss the Medicare arrangements, there was a battle royal between the State Ministers and the Federal Minister for Health about the distribution of funds under Medicare. The Federal Minister said: 'We will give you an extra $700m so that you can provide free out-patient treatment and free beds in public hospitals to people, regardless of their means. That is Australian Labor Party policy. We will pay you an extra $700m worth of taxpayers' funds to do this'. One would have thought that, being State Labor Ministers for Health, they would have been delighted at this, but they looked the gift horse in the mouth.

The Commonwealth estimated that there would be an increse of about 4 per cent in out-patient services. The Commonwealth officials, supported by the Federal Minister, said that if out-patient services previously cost something and they were now going to be free this would result in an increase of about 4 per cent in extra out-patient services. Similarly, if, under the free in-patient bed arrangements one could have a free hospital bed, regardless of means, and did not have to insure privately, the Federal officials said that there would be a drop of about 4 per cent in the number of privately insured patients in public hospitals. A privately insured patient in a public hospital is very important to the hospital because the hospital can get money from a private insurance fund to add to its running expenses. In addition to the money the hospital can get through the State and Commonwealth treasuries it can get extra money from the private health fund of a privately insured patient. Therefore if the number of privately insured patients in a hospital drops it has a significant effect on hospital revenue.

The Federal Minister came along to this conference and said: 'We think, on the basis of our knowledge and experience-and with Sir Humphrey advising us and so on-that there will be a 4 per cent drop in the revenues from privately insured patients'. The State Health Ministers, led by the Australian Labor Party Ministers, said: 'We think you are talking nonsense. We think that the drop will be 14 per cent or 15 per cent, on the basis of our experience and our feeling about what people will do if they are offered something which is allegedly free' . But the basis of the reimbursements, the basis of the Federal-State agreement on finances for health, was that there would be a drop of about 4 per cent in revenues as a result of extra numbers of free out-patients and uninsured private patients in the hospital beds.

Who was correct-the Federal Minister or the State Ministers? I have been doing a certain amount of scouting around in the public hospitals and I understand, on pretty reliable evidence, that the out-patient numbers in the public hospitals are up by about 15 per cent, as forecast by the State Labor Ministers-then Messrs Brereton, Roper, Cornwall and others. Their estimate proves to be correct for out-patients. With regard to how many additional uninsured patients have been taking the in-patient beds, the number of insured in-patients has gone down by about 10 per cent. In that case the State Ministers have been about two- thirds right and the Federal Minister about one-third right. But still there is a very substantial difference between the 4 per cent estimated by the Federal Minister and the 10 per cent in reality being experienced by the hospitals around Australia. This is of major concern. These are the figures for the major teaching hospitals.

There has been another difficulty in this Federal-State arrangement; that is, that the Medicare arrangements require, in relation to a patient who is in some considerable difficulty in a public hospital but is privately insured, a certificate at the end of 35 days-previously it was 60 days-declaring that the patient requires acute care. A doctor, at the risk of incurring a fine of $10, 000 or five years in gaol, has to sign a certificate saying that that patient requires continuing acute care. Understandably, there has been a reluctance on the part of many doctors to sign such certificates. They do not want to risk the fine or the five years in gaol. As a result, many patients who would previously have stayed in public hospitals for more than 35 days at the full reimbursement rate from the private funds have now had their rates of reimbursement reduced, further reducing the revenues of the public hospitals.

What are the end results? Public hospitals have many more out-patients than they expected? They have a bigger proportion of non-paying patients in their beds. Many more patients are being thrown out after 35 days who previously would have been there a bit longer and paid through private funds. The end result is that the States are still incurring the costs of treating these patients but are losing revenues at a vastly greater rate than was estimated by the Federal Government in its Medicare plans. When we talk about a general amount of $700m or $800m and about these sorts of shortfalls it is clear that the States will lose over the course of the year at least $100m in revenues that they expected to receive and, indeed, had budgeted for.

I inform the House that I have reports from State Ministers, most of them Labor , that they are preparing a case for vastly increased revenue grants from the Commonwealth over the ensuing year. The Supply that is to be granted under this Bill is not sufficient to meet the States' needs, and this, of course, has important budgetary implications for the Federal Government and the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating). Medicare has been undercosted yet again, I would think by at least $100m, on the hospital component alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that make it up to?

—If I may respond to the honourable member for Mitchell, who has a concern about these matters, in my view it makes it up to considerably more than the amount raised by the levy of one per cent of income that has been put down on the people. If the Government were honest it would have to be considering an increase in the Medicare levy. We already know that the Medicare levy accounts for only one-eighth of total health expenditure. Australia spends about $8 billion a year on health costs at Federal and State levels. The levy of one per cent raises only $1 billion.
—It should be 8c then.

—As my friend the honourable member for Dawson said, the levy should be 8c in the dollar. The trick about this, of course, is that people are told: ' Medicare is cheap; it costs only one per cent of your taxable income'. In fact, it costs eight times that amount. The people pay the rest through their ordinary tax. I suggest that, instead of being honest, the Government will not put up the levy to at least 1.5 or 2 per cent as it should to account for these hospital differences but will merely increase the general rate of taxation in the next Budget to cover these increased hospital charges.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally, taxpayers will pay more because many people who can afford to insure for their medical and hospital costs do not have to do so because they can enjoy free treatment, in-patient and out-patient, in the hospitals under Medicare. Two patients with equal incomes can be in beds side by side, one having failed to insure and paying nothing for the bed and the person in the next bed, having taken out private insurance to ensure a choice of doctor, paying $80 a day for the very same bed. I think that is outrageous and a disgrace.

There is another aspect to this problem and that is the pressure on the private hospitals. This is related to the public hospital situation. Obviously, if there is pressure on the private hospitals and the private hospitals are not receiving as many patients as they should, more people have to go into the public hospitals. What happens in private hospitals directly affects what happens in the public hospitals. A central objective of Medicare was to put a squeeze on the private hospitals. This is done in three ways. The first is by telling people that regardless of their means under Medicare they can have a free bed in a public hospital if they do not want choice of doctor. In other words, the Minister for Health says: 'Do not bother to insure; merely pay the Medicare levy which is compulsory anyway and you can have a free bed in a public hospital even if you are a millionaire'. The Labor Party says that millionaires can have free beds in public hospitals. That is its policy.

Secondly, it says that a concerned person who really wants to have the choice of his own doctor and the capacity to sack his doctor if he is not getting good service must insure privately, but if he insures privately he pays $80 a day for a bed in a public hospital. A person who does not insure pays nothing, therefore more people will not bother to insure. For the person who still takes out private hospital insurance there is a further problem in that the Government has categorised all the private hospitals to reduce the amount of money that a person can get back through insurance.

The final thing to militate against private hospitals in Australia is the application to them of the 35-day rule. Again, a doctor, on pain of a $10,000 fine or five years in gaol, has to sign a certificate to say that the patient is sufficiently ill to remain in the private hospital, otherwise the patient will be chucked out. Whether there is somewhere for the patient to go is a problem because there has been a total freeze on nursing home beds under the Hawke Government. There has not been a single new nursing home bed approval since the Hawke Government took over. So if one is unfortunate enough to have no doctor to sign a certificate to say that one is still sick enough to stay in a private hospital or as a private patient in a public hospital, and if there is no nursing home bed to go to, one is in a lot of trouble. Many families in Australia are currently in that trouble. This is another factor which adds to the squeeze on the private hospitals. As a result, in the first few months of Medicare there has been a sharp decline in the occupancy of beds in private hospitals.

Again, in my going around the traps and talking to people in the private hospitals, I understand there has been a 30 per cent drop in occupancy in most cases in private hospitals since the introduction of Medicare. In other words, the intention of this Government is actually being achieved-a squeeze on private hospitals to try to force people into public hospitals. But where are the patients going? They can hardly go into the major teaching hospitals as they were already stretched to the limit under the previous squeeze policy. Therefore the queues are lengthening. It is impossible for me, despite all my inquiries, to find out what the exact period of waiting is in the public hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, up to two years they tell me.

—The honourable member for Mitchell says it is up to two years. I know that there are grave problems in the western suburbs of Sydney. These lists are closely guarded. I cannot get hold of them. It is well known that the cardiac surgery waiting list in Sydney is at least three months. For hip replacements and other orthopaedic work of various kinds it is much worse. A report in the Age of 1 May headed 'Chief surgeon quits over long delays for patients', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The chief of orthopaedic surgery at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, Mr Kingsley Mills, has resigned because he says he can no longer take the frustration and worry of watching patient waiting lists grow.

Mr Mills said yesterday that about 900 patients, most with painful conditions, faced indefinite delays for orthopaedic surgery at the Royal Melbourne Hospital. The list was increasing and many of the patients, needing knee and hip replacements, could not afford private hospitals.

'There is a constant anxiety at the back of your mind about it. Our registrars are getting six or more calls a day from people on the waiting list hoping something can be done for them,' Mr Mills said.
'I feel I have done everything in my power to improve the situation . . . I have reached a point where I really feel I can't go any further.'
Mr Mills said that because of the hospital budget cuts, orthopaedic surgeons were now largely concerned with emergency work while patients with painful non- fatal conditions waited indefinitely.
This is a disgraceful situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the British experience all over again.

—As my friend, the honourable member for Dawson says, this is the British national health system all over again. All I can say is that if this Government continues with its determination to nationalise every health dollar, to take total control through Federal and State governments of every element of health care delivery, if it wants to squeeze out private hospitals, private insurance, private health dollars and private choice giving people some capacity to provide for themselves, it will have no option but to continue to turn the screw on individual patients whose needs are of absolutely no concern to cold hearted administrators. Our views on health are that there must be choice, there must be the capacity for private insurance and there must be the capacity for more dollars to come into this situation through private sources to relieve these difficulties in our country's hospitals.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems in being on this side of the House is that unfortunately those opposite seem to have great trouble in recognising that there has been a change of government and that in some sense the electorate has made some decisions and we, in this place, have made some decisions, and Medicare is one of them. It is as though we have to back and go over that battle again. I will do so very briefly in a moment, because of the attitude of the Opposition. However, I think that when we look at the Opposition 's record it does not have a lot to argue for.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has indicated, the States ( Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill 1984 is concerned with two areas of amendment. One relates to the question of laboratories-to give effect to an agreement with the States, made in the context of the negotiation of the Medicare agreements, that general purpose payments to the States after 30 June 1984 would be reduced by amounts in respect of the operation of Commonwealth pathology laboratories not taken over by the States.

That is the intent of the first amendment. As the honourable member for Mackellar has said, and as the Minister representing the Minister for Health, the Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford) said in his second reading speech, in effect this measure is to bring back money to the Federal Government that the States had not used because they had not taken over the operation of those laboratories. I understand that the Opposition is not opposing that. I will not labour that point except to say that those who are listening might think that the Commonwealth is being a little tough with the States and that we are taking back from them money that a previous government had agreed to give to the States with the one exception of Western Australia, which State took up that option. As the honourable member for Mackellar has said , it is not appropriate to be paying the States twice in that sense, so we are bringing the money back.

I remind the House and the community that at the June-July 1983 Premiers Conference the Commonwealth agreed to provide an extra temporary additional revenue assistance grant of $155.5m. This was in recognition of the unusually severe budgetary conditions that the States were facing. The intention, in effect, was to try to alleviate some of the budgetary difficulties that we, as a Federal Government, saw the States facing. One could dwell for some time on the difficulties and the shortcomings of the previous Government in its dealings with the States, but obviously that is not the spirit of this debate. The intention is to try to look ahead somewhat. But certainly if we were to try to make any point about this first item, clearly we are taking some money back because in a sense if we did not we would be paying the States twice. But I balance the account by saying that in the last Premiers Conference this additional $155.5m, that the Federal Government has granted the States was intended to try to alleviate some of their budgetary difficulties.

Obviously there were some severe budgetary difficulties experienced by the States. They were as a result, generally speaking, of the economic recession that they were experiencing and as a consequence of a reduction in the general revenue position of the States. In addition to that, we felt that the States could play a significant part in economic recovery. We felt that by putting further funds into the State arena that recovery would be assisted. Clearly that has been successful. The recovery is beginning. I might add for the record-I think this is important-that the historical experience of Premiers conferences has, if anything been a hysterical experience; that usually there have been a series of public announcements by various Premiers saying how unhappy they are about the arrangements being agreed to between the Federal and State governments .

Last year the Premiers Conference was the first one in which a degree of consensus was established between the Federal Government and the State Premiers. That is a very important achievement. It followed on the successful National Economic Summit Conference. We found we were able to get agreement between ourselves at the Federal level and the States to get some recognition about both the direction of grants to States and the Australian Loan Council arrangements. Obviously the $155.5m was given to try to show the good faith of the Federal Government in this respect. So I point out, on this first item we are dealing with, that the Federal Government is cognisant of its responsibilities towards the States, and its work with respect to the Premiers Conference is an example of that.

The honourable member for Mackellar wanted to talk about the second item, which deals with enabling legislation to allow payments to continue to the States until 30 June 1985. He then began to devote some specific attention to some of those provisions with respect to Medicare and the health funding arrangements with the States. As I said at the outset, quite clearly it is as if we will have to fight this battle over and over again. In fact, the Medicare decisions, which were made in this chamber and which to some extent have been made by the community, are being reworked by the Opposition. I guess that is fair enough because it is part of the role of this place. It is also part of the role of this place for honourable members opposite to bring out areas in which they believe we could make amendments to improve the overall picture.

I wish to take up one or two items which I think deserve some comment. The Opposition spokesman on health matters talked to some extent about the role of choice of doctor in relation to patients. I think that is a spurious argument. It is spurious in the sense that it is one argument which has been heightened considerably by doctors and to some extent by some commentators in the political arena when they say that that is the be all and end all of the Medicare linkage. In fact, we do not want to remove the choice of doctor, and to some extent we have not done that. I think it is also necessary to say that it is a bit fictitious to say that everyone who is ill spends his or her time trying to figure out who is the best doctor to get treated by. The experience tends to be the opposite; there is a degree of linkage between the general practitioner whom one attends and the sort of specialist to whom the GP might refer one. To a considerable extent the community is quite dependent upon the skill, the knowledge, the expertise and the professionalism of doctors in making appropriate referrals. To that extent the choice is a mini-choice, if one likes. It is a choice which the doctors make within an established framework.

Quite obviously, if we were to talk about choice in the widest possible sense we might indeed have a debate. I think it is a spurious argument to talk about choice as if somehow everyone who is ill gets hold of the yellow pages and sits down and says: 'Who will I consult today?' It does not happen, and the Opposition knows it does not happen. Clearly, the doctors know it does not happen. It is one of those mythical things which are given great prominence.

Interestingly, circumstances in recent times have changed. The accounting profession is advertising in an attempt to develop some choice between accountants. Again one might say there is a need perhaps to have some choice in accounting practice. But I think we have to go back to this position: It is largely a mythical claim that somehow the choice involving people going through some sort of yellow pages exercise in seeking out a doctor is the high point of medicine.

I wish to make another point. The Opposition spokesman on health has made an interesting claim about increases in costs. I think honourable members opposite have to share the responsibility in this place and in the wider community. When Medicare was introduced-honourable members opposite should bear in mind that Medicare was one of the issues on which we went to the electorate and it was a matter on which the electorate gave us a clear indication of its preference, and it was voted through the Parliament of Australia-the doctors were unwilling to accept the real implications of Medicare. Some honourable members in this place assisted the doctors in their refusal to co-operate with the effective arrangements of Medicare. So when the Opposition talks about cost problems relating to Medicare, it must have a clear look at itself. I think honourable members opposite have to make an assessment and say: 'Have we adopted the widest possible opinion and view about Medicare?'. I think the answer is no, the Opposition has not and that in fact its performance has left a little to be desired. When we begin to talk about the question of costs of Medicare in Australia, clearly we have had some difficulty, and the public is aware of it, in dealing with the medical profession. Honourable members in this place also have a responsibility to try to talk about fiscal responsibility. I do not believe that responsibility was shown in every case.

I also take up another matter that the honourable member for Mackellar raised, that is, the issue of the 35-day rule compared with the 60-day rule. We would argue that the decision we have made is a more responsible decision, because we are trying to tailor the sorts of payments and benefit levels more appropriately to the conditions being experienced in the medical field. I have spoken in support of this Bill, to which there are two amendments. I have indicated the substance of those amendments. Some other matters were raised by the honourable member for Mackellar concerning the operation of Medicare. We are confident that it is proceeding well. We are confident that we can administer it effectively in terms of fiscal responsibility, and I am pleased to commend the Bill to the House.

In an age where we are talking about having babies at home, we are proposing to take the opportunity for local maternity care further away from the family situation. DEBATE.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Mr Uren:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition gives its full support to the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1984. The Opposition also welcomes the opportunity of participating in a fuller debate on local government as this is the first opportunity this Parliament has had available to it since Labor entered into government on 5 March 1983-over 14 months ago. Because this is a rare opportunity and because of the importance of local government's 838 authorities throughout Australia, the Opposition firstly condemns the Government for its original intention of introducing this Bill with another for cognate debate and, now that the Opposition has forced its separate debate, the severe limitation in the time allowed by the Government for that full debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting that during the course of this afternoon the Government was shamed into a further and wider debate on migration. It is not prepared to have a wider debate on this very important subject of local government. One wonders what local government has to do to be the subject of a significant debate in Parliament. Does it have to call rape or murder, or does it have to say it has been plundered by its brother governments? This indicates to me that for too long the media has given very little preference to local government in regard to what it believes are newsworthy items. One wonders, again, how the Government can be shamed into holding a fuller debate on this very important sphere of government.

The Opposition firmly believes in the principle of local government as an important and necessary part of government in Australia. Its 10,500 elected representatives throughout the Commonwealth perform almost in a volunteer and unpaid capacity in providing those services so close to the interests of the constituents. For those reasons alone this Bill deserves the fullest debate by this Parliament-an opportunity denied it for the past 14 months except for the matter of public importance introduced by the Opposition on 8 September last year. It has been the Opposition over the 14 months of the Labor Government that has consistently brought to the Parliament's attention the shortcomings of its performance in regard to local government in relation not only to its promise but also its own policy.
In its first Budget of August 1983, the Government had the opportunity to honour its policy in respect of real term guarantees, and I wish to quote from its own policy document in this regard:

Labor will allocate annually at least 2 per cent of the federal personal income tax as a general revenue grant to local government: The allocation in any year to be not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—It is another broken pre-election promise. Standing order No. 293 prevents all but 'the Minister' initiating an amendment to a taxation or money proposal. The Opposition will provide an in principle amendment to the second reading and invites the Government and the Minister to take the opportunity of further amending the principal Act to provide this measure of justice to local government throughout Australia as it itself promised and its policy provides. States of Australia have a minimum guarantee of a 1 per cent real term improvement yet local government, the third sphere of government, is not guaranteed even a retention of real values. The need for such an amendment serves as a notice to local authorities in Australia that in actual fact the Australian Labor Party has, firstly, no policy on local government; secondly, has a policy it does not intend to implement or, thirdly, has a policy it does not intend to publicise-that is, this Labor Government is leaning towards more centralist control over local government.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to the principal Act is to ensure that payments of personal income tax made under the prescribed payment system of Division 3A of Part VI of the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1936 are included into the definition of gross personal income tax collections for the purposes of determining local government 's proportion of personal income tax sharing. It is expected to increase the grant to local government for the following 1984-85 by an additional $2m to $3m. Also, the amendment intends that while local govenment participates in the collection of additional taxes and penalty taxation, there will be deducted the amount of interest that the Commissioner of Taxation now is obliged to pay to taxpayers on tax refunds in certain circumstances when determining the net income tax collections.

The principal Act was introduced into this Parliament in 1976 by the Fraser Government as evidence of its understanding of local government's need for an unconditional general grant to assist authorities in the financing of its many services at a time of high inflation when pressure was mounting against the rate payer, the traditional source of local government revenue. This government still has to learn the message that local government needs open, unconditional grants to provide the services that in many cases have been transferred from the Commonwealth-such as health, libraries, welfare, child care and aged care, just to mention a few.

Tied grants, which the Minister will claim have now reached record levels, are not in themselves the answer, and certainly are not a substitute for the freedom of choice that councillors and aldermen are able to exercise in the spending of the general purpose grants. Local councillors see the needs at a local level more readily and clearly than does the Canberra politician or bureaucrat. It is for that reason that the legislation of 1976 was the biggest break-through for local government since its inception, because the Commonwealth recognised its liability to local government in the form of that personal income tax sharing grant.

Prior to that, the Whitlam Government had provided untied grants to councils on a regional basis where there were disabilities which could be demonstrated and recognised. Through this avenue, local government became eligible for assistance to provide assistance to child care, arts, leisure and recreation, and were invited to participate in the Australian Assistance Plan and the regional employment development schemes. It is therefore regrettable that this present Labor Government has not sought to build on to these earlier successful initiatives of both Labor and Liberal-National Party governments by maintaining the real value of the grants from year to year.

Yesterday the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) complained in the House that notices of motion had been given on many occasions, but they were not given the debate that some of them warranted. I have given many notices of motion in the House on local government matters that have not been given the benefit of any debate at all, so I wonder how interested the Special Minister of State is in getting this debate going. In one of those notices of motion I took the opportunity of pointing out to the Government that perhaps there should be a change in regard to the wording of the legislation itself to provide for its policy. It is to the shame of the Government that it has not sought to have that notice of motion debated or endeavoured to keep at least that part of the promise and policy of the Australian Labor Party to ensure that the allocation of general revenue grants to local government will not be less than the real value of the previous year's allocation.

As a result of this Government's neglect, local government was denied $13m in the 1983-84 allocation as the Government allowed the real value of the grant to diminish by 3 per cent in that year to below the value of the 1982-83 grant. I believe it can be described as a win for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) in what can only be described as a miserable, penny-pinching exercise. These differences resulted in a further delay before the grants were quantified and distributed and local government authorities lost not only the $13m but interest as well on the delayed payment of the grant. It will be very interesting to see just how much conscience this Government and its back bench members have and to see whether the Government is prepared to meet up to its obligations under its policies and promises. This particular promise certainly was not expected to be included in the handful of dollars sometimes snatched back after a successful election, something which Mr Hawke said in yet another discredited pre-election promise would not happen. I believe that promise was thoroughly understood by local government to mean that there should be a matching of real values.

Even before preparing for this debate, I could predict the Government's hollow responses, particularly drawing on certain prepared statistics on tied grants from the 1982-83 Budget. The same programs that are used to bolster the Government's local government argument on funding are used over and over again by the Government in other quarters. The community employment programs in the Commonwealth Employment Service are also used, as are the jobs on local roads program in the transport area, the local airport ownership program in the aviation area and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall now quote comments of Mrs Cutts, the Director of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations in Local Government Administration of December 1983 on local government doubts about tied grants. Mrs Cutts stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Local Government won't say no to offers of specific purpose funding, but the dangling carrot must not be taken at the expense of the revenue sharing arrangements which provide for a share of taxpayers' funds to reach all councils according to an equitable distribution process.
Why the reluctance to pin too much reliance on tied funding from Federal sources?
Experience has shown that a Federal Government can perceive increased tied funding as a substitute to untied funds.

Tied funding tends to distort local priorities. With program life being either short or unspecified, councils feel vulnerable. They fear that community expectations will be raised unrealistically as to the council's capacity (i.e. the local community's capacity) to continue to provide the service once Federal funding is restricted.

Tied funding implies a centralised submission assessment process and Local Government is dubious of the capacity of Federal Bureaucrats to accurately assess relative claims for assistance by local communities across the continent.

The community employment program is an average example of the effects of these tied grants where the guidelines are given to achieve the Federal Government's objective of seeking local government sponsors in high unemployment areas to employ a defined category of those unemployed. The necessity of having to choose that special category of men and women and the mix mean that this expenditure of funds is not as efficient, economic or productive as the means by which local government carries out its own programs in accordance with its own priorities. Mrs Cutts' response to the CEP initiatives was:

Yes, we are very sensitive to the impact of unemployment on our local communities, and yes, we will endeavour to re-order either our revenue or expenditure priorities in order to find the resources to buy into the scheme but if you were to give us an equivalent additional untied grant through the revenue sharing arrangements, we could create new employment oportunities far more successfully than will be possible under the complex provisions of the CEP.

I refer to the chart I had earlier incorporated in that the claim is made by the Government that the expenditure to local government increased from $687m to $994m or by 45 per cent against an inflation rate over the past 12 months of 11. 2 per cent. In 1982-83, the general purpose grant was 62 per cent of the total grant. In 1983-84, this grant reduced to 47 per cent of the total grant. This comparison shows the massive shift from the desired goal of local government to have a greater proportion of untied grants to the achievement of the preferred result of a central government of tying up grants so as to make local government more dependent on Canberra.

Let us look at the result of expenditure on the aerodrome local ownership plan. This is not distributed to local government in all circumstances. Again, it is an example of the manner in which political licence is exercised by this Government in order to describe its program. In fact, a large proportion of the expenditure last year and this year would have been to the Cairns Port Authority which is not a local government authority in itself. The point is, however, that the Cairns Port Authority found after the opening of the international airport that the security police were to be withdrawn and the Authority now has to suffer the expenditure of employing and paying its own security force. That is just one of the many continuing items of expenditure made necessary through the receipt of a tied grant and obviously not disclosed during the negotiations.

On examination of the graph, one looks at the direct payments and appreciates how far local government has moved from providing property-related services financed through rates on land to providing community or people-related services , such as health and welfare. Of this year's allocation health and welfare services are to receive $4.9m; aged persons homes and centres, $17.7m; home care , $8m; child care, $26.4m; arts and national estate, $0.79m; airports, $44.7m; and special employment programs, $104.4m. The Northern Territory receives additional amounts to the extent of direct grants of its own of $14m.

Apart from roads and water programs which traditionally receive direct grants and are treated accordingly, these services, if examined carefully, are responsibilities of the Federal Government, constitutionally and financially. So why all the fuss about the great generosity of Government when it is paying that for which it is constitutionally responsible and is delivering these programs through the courtesy of local government participation. These tied grants or direct payments do not include the total cost of these programs, either capital or recurrent, in the hands of local government. More and more, local government has been called upon to bear a greater financial cost in these Commonwealth programs from its own rating revenue.

Basically, it was partly in recognition of these extra and unascertained costs, that the Commonwealth entered into the personal income tax sharing arrangements, such funds being distributed through the States grants commissions on a formula that required a minimum distribution of 30 per cent on a population basis. Otherwise, it was entirely untied and free for local government authorities to use as they themselves found to be the most desirable manner in the interests of their constituents. It is interesting to note that at no time has there been an adequate inquiry into the proper share of Federal revenues to which local government is properly entitled for its discharge of Commonwealth programs.

The PIT share, commenced at the rate of 1.52 per cent, increased in 1979 to 1. 75 per cent and in 1980 to the existing 2 per cent. Until the 1983-84 year, the formula allowed local government to participate in real growth of 36.6 per cent under the Fraser Government. Only in 1983-84 were real values decreased by 3 per cent for the first time, which was significantly the action of this Labor Government. Apparently at no time has there been any justification of the percentage, by an inquiry to determine the adequacy of the grant. In the Budget of August last year it was announced that the Government had decided to appoint an independent committee to review local govenment financing, with particular attention to the operation of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976.

Now nine months later the terms of reference and the membership of this Committee have yet to be announced. This is just not good enough. The delay of nine months already may well be seen as justice denied after expectations had been raised by the Federal Government. What concerns me about this proposed inquiry is that while it might examine the use of PIT funds by local government it apparently will do nothing to determine local governments' proper allocation of Federal revenues as a right.

Tonight I wish to put forward a scenario which I believe is worthwhile considering. However, I think I ought to mention that, because of Australia's very poor record in the participation of offsets, it might be advantageous to ask the unions of this country whether they can look at the offsets that are available and determine in which areas Australia is capable of participating. I think that the unions may well have a better idea than those captains of industry.

I now return to the scenario. I suggest that if this country is to prosper it must look at its defence expenditure and at overall needs in a complete context and not in isolation. Currently the Royal Australian Navy is looking at the purchase of a replacement helicopter. The choice has been narrowed down to two- the light Wessex Lynx Mark 3 or the medium duty Sikorsky Seahawk helicopter. There is a substantial difference in the price of these helicopters, not surprisingly because they are different types of machines.

I think we ought to consider that probably the best anti-submarine helicopter in the world today is the Sea King, of which we have eight and which we are not using. The frigates for which we are buying helicopters envisage these helicopters to be observation, gunnery control, reconnaisance, communications type utility helicopters and not primarily anti-submarine helicopters. That role could be filled adequately by either the Lynx or the Sea King. However, the Sea King, being a heavy helicopter, would require $65m worth of alterations to our frigates which would make it an extremely expensive purchase. I suggest that consideration be given to purchasing a redundant ship from the Australian National Line and, at the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd, making that ship into a flat top ship which would be capable of carrying helicopters. I suggest that we put our Sea Kings to sea again to give our fleet enhanced submarine protection. All this could be done out of the money we would save by making the Navy buy the Wessex rather than the more expensive Seahawk Sikorsky.

When it comes to defence we are not in the business of buying toys for the boys ; we are in the business of getting the very best value for the Australian dollar. I suggest that the best value for Australia is not just in what might be a marginally better machine but in the overall integration of Australia's needs. After all, ultimately the defence of this country will be in the hearts and minds of the people. I suggest that employed people have far more to fight for than unemployed people.

Having made considerable savings in the purchase of the Wessex rather than the Sea King, we should then look to integrate its manufacture into Australian industry. The United Kingdom probably has the gratest expertise in the world today in this area of technology. I suggest that by marrying this expertise with Australian private industry and government participation we could have in this country a helicopter manufacturing industry that would be not only efficient but also export-oriented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to some of the communication problems of the deaf. I am particularly pleased that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is present in the House and is able to take note of the matter to which I am about to address myself. I was also greatly assisted in coming to an understanding of the problems of the deaf by Mr Lex Busch, who resides near Bairnsdale, in my electorate and who has two adult sons who were born deaf.

SPEECH.PARA: There appear to be three problems in communications for the deaf. The first is the cost of teletex equipment which is needed to pick up, so to speak, the captioning some programs send out. By that I mean that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and some commercial television stations send out a signal which, if decoded by the teletex equipment, will provide a printed word on the television screen. It goes without saying that that is of great assistance to the deaf in their enjoyment of a program. Regrettably, it is very expensive. The Minister has been able to assist by freeing teletex equipment from sales tax. Previously sales tax on teletex equipment was 32.5 per cent. That has been abolished, which is certainly a step in the right direction.

The second major problem is the amount of captioning that the ABC and commercial stations provide. At this time, due to technical and expenditure problems, I suggest that the amount of captioning is nowhere near satisfactory. I understand from the Minister that, at the moment, it is available in ABC programs only to the extent of some seven hours in Sydney and Melbourne. Only a few commercial television stations have captioning, most notably Carson's Law, Sons and Daughters and 60 Minutes. I urge the Minister and the Government to provide as much financial assistance for the establishment of better translators so as to provide the facility for increased captioning.

The third major problem in communications for the deaf, if honourable members will excuse the long definition, is a Porta-Printer telephone typewriter, better known as TTY. This is plugged in to the phone and it operates like a telex. It costs over $600, and it is required that both the speaker and the receiver of the telephone have this equipment. Of course, there is no voice, but again it goes without saying that it comes out by way of telex. The equipment is expensive, and I have made representations to the Minister on that. I should add that the $600 is on top of the normal telephone installation charges and rental costs. The Minister is aware of this problem. He tells me that a one-third discount is available on rental and installation fees. Telecom Australia is aware of its responsibilities to the disabled, particularly, the deaf, and is working on increasing the range and availability of products. However, with respect to the Minister and the Government, I do not believe that we are moving fast enough in this direction. It is obviously a matter of great importance. In this space age I believe that we ought to be assisting in providing the disadvantaged deaf in our community with as many telecommunications facilities as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast to these constructive and well intentioned statements, the outburst by the Northern Territory's Chief Minister reported in today's Australian is neither constructive nor well intentioned. Indeed, it appears to be motivated by a desperate attempt to find a scapegoat, an obsession with Canberra bashing and cheap political point scoring. This outburst hurts the Territory, its mining industry, its people and its prospects of maintaining harmonious race relations. It normally would not deserve a reply, but I think some of the more extreme claims should not stand unchallenged. Let me deal with three of the major claims . I deal firstly with the question of the freeze. The article in today's Australian states:
The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, rekindled the land rights issue yesterday with an astonishing attack on three federal admin- istrations . . .

Mr Everingham made it clear the Territory blamed the Federal Government and the previous Fraser and Whitlam administration for 'using Aboriginal land rights as the vehicle' to cause a 12-year freeze on mining exploration and development on Crown land.

I think the Chief Minister needs a lesson in history. Firstly, the freeze was lifted by his Government in December 1981, well before this Government came to power. So I do not see how he can be blaming us. Secondly, while the freeze was introduced by the Whitlam Government and maintained by it for two and a half years, it was kept in place by the Fraser Government for six years. As Mr Justice Toohey points out in his report, it is the freeze and not so much the Act that is apparently the cause of many of the problems experienced by miners in the Northern Territory at present.

The Northern Territory Government had an opportunity to remove the freeze when it obtained self-government in July 1978. Indeed, it could have done that at any time between July 1978 and December 1981, when it finally did so. It let it stay in place for three and a half years. On top of that, the Country Liberal Party has controlled the Legislative Council or Assembly in the Northern Territory since 1974. It has had ample opportunity over all that time to persuade the Whitlam Government and later its political colleagues in the Fraser Government that the freeze should be removed, and it did not do it. So the Northern Territory Government wears the responsibility, if there is any wearing to be done, for the freeze and its adverse effects as much if not more than anyone else.

The second factor is the Toohey report. The Chief Minister is reported to have slammed Mr Justice Toohey's recent review of the Act for having further entrenched and perpetuated its problems. On the contrary, I think the Toohey report set out some very good and constructive suggestions on how the Act might be improved. I do not agree with the Chief Minister. At the same time, I do not agree with everything in the Toohey report. The Northern Territory Government takes a strange approach to this issue. We have this morning's report of what the Chief Minister said and we have the Northern Territory Government's response to the Toohey report. Of the 47 recommendations of the 120 in the Toohey report that the Northern Territory Government addresses in its response, it opposes 12 outright. I want to draw attention to the fact that there was a grounding of aircraft. I know that that occurred because there was a series of four Notices to Airmen- Notams-upon which Mr Eddie Ward based his concern on that occasion, which I personally as a young teacher in western New South Wales-in Broken Hill- forwarded to the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr Evatt. Undoubtedly Dr Evatt then referred those Notams to Mr Ward, who took the issue up.

The Notams appear to indicate that the explosion was intended to take place on 9 September because all flights of civilian aircraft through the area were subject to approval by air traffic control. The explosion did not take place until the 27th, when further Notams were issued prohibiting flights at all altitudes wihtin the area defined by map references. I have taken advantage of the opportunity to plot those roughly on a map. The first Notam requires approval of flights in an area surrounding Maralinga and covering most of South Australia. When the actual explosion took place, it is quite clear, from the map reference, that that atomic cloud extended over a large part of South Australia. It intruded into south western Queensland and into north western New South Wales , including apparently the city where I was at the time, Broken Hill. It was a very significant area which was undoubtedly covered by an atomic cloud which resulted from that explosion at Maralinga on 27 September 1956.

Finally, I draw attention to the fact that while Mr Eddie Ward's credibility was questioned by the nature of the answer that was given by the Minister, Mr Beale, on that occasion, his question was based on matters of substance. I know they were matters of substance because I provided the information.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Aboriginal Development Commission approved finance for the purchase of a hotel in Walgett, New South Wales; if so, (a) what is the name of the incorporated body that purchased the hotel, (b) what was the purchase price, (c) what decision-making procedures were adopted by the Aboriginal Development Commission to enable them to consider the purchase of such a property in Walgett , (d) were any feasibility studies carried out regarding the purchase of the hotel, (e) who was responsible for initiating the idea of the purchase of the hotel and (f) was there any consultation with the local Aboriginal community before the purchase of the hotel; if so, when did that consultation take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Aboriginal Development Commission approved finance in 1983 for the purchase of the Oasis Hotel/Motel in Walgett, New South Wales;

(a) the hotel/motel was purchased by the Commission under section 28 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980 on behalf of the Barwon Aboriginal Community Limited, the representative Aboriginal organisation in Walgett;
(b) the purchase price was $419,000, comprising $329,000 for the freehold title and $90,000 for the tenancy vacancy and licence;
(c) the following procedures were adopted by the Commission in considering the purchase of the hotel/motel:
(i) receipt of a submission from the Aboriginal community at Walgett;
(ii) engagement of a consultant to carry out a feasibility study;
(iii) engagement of a registered valuer with expertise in hotels/motels;
(iv) engagement of an architectual firm to provide a report on the structural soundness of the building;
(v) engagement of a firm of solicitors to carry out a full range of searches; and
(vi) investigations by staff from the Central, Regional and Area Offices of the Commission.
(d) as mentioned in (c), a feasibility study was carried out by a firm of consultants;

(e) the idea of purchasing the hotel/motel was initiated by the members and directors of the Barwon Aboriginal Community Limited and endorsed by public meetings of the Aboriginal community at Walgett on 21 March and 17 May 1983; and

(f) consultation between the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Aboriginal community at Walgett concerning the purchase of the hotel/motel began in January 1983 and resulted in a formal submission being lodged with the Commission in March 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What quantity of cheese was imported into Australia from the European Economic Community before a duty of $1,000 per tonne on Danish blue vein, German rinded edam and Dutch rinded gouda was imposed.
(2) Was this duty later reduced to $800 per tonne and a larger range of cheese types included; if so, what was the range of cheese types.
(3) Did the level of cheese imports increase to 19,740 tonnes in 1982-83.

(4) Was the imposition of the duties due to the fact that the wholesale price in Denmark was $3,700 per tonne of cheese and the landed priced in Australia for the same cheeses was $2,800; if so, did this have the effect on one Australian manufacturing company-the Downs Co-operative Dairy Association, Toowoomba, Queensland-being forced to cut production of cheese made on its premises because of unfair competition from highly subsidised imports from the EEC.
(5) What is the present position in respect of the effect of subsidised imports on this company.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The rate of tariff duty on imports of blue vein, edam and gouda cheeses has remained unchanged in recent years at $96 per tonne. However cash securities of $1,010 per tonne for blue vein and $1,050 for edam and gouda were imposed on imports of these cheeses from certain EEC countries from 24 June 1983 to 17 November 1983. The imposition of cash securities equal to the level of subsidy estimated to be received by these cheeses followed a preliminary determination of injury by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) in respect of a complaint brought by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference (ADIC) against imports of these cheeses varieties from specified EEC countries. In line with established procedures cash securities were imposed pending the completion of the ACS inquiries and a final determination.

Following extensive discussions, the EEC provided a satisfactory price undertaking which, by removing the element of injury, provided the basis for not proceeding to a final countervailing duty determination.
The key features of the arrangement concluded with the EEC are:

the EEC has agreed to manage export refund payment levels on exports to Australia with the aim of ensuring the prices of cheeses covered by the undertaking will be at a level which does not disturb the Australian market

in contrast to the cvd action initially brought by ADIC, a very wide range of cheeses is covered by the arrangement including blue vein, edam, gouda, cheddar, colby, monterey, cantal, cheshire, wensleydale, lancashire, blarney, double gloucester, havarti, danbo, fontal, fontina, fynbo, maribo, samso and tilsit.
EEC export subsidies have been reduced, on all these cheeses, initially by $800 per tonne from the level previously applying of around $1,000 per tonne
The AIDC was closely involved in all stages of the discussions with the EEC concerning the cheese arrangement and have welcomed the agreement.

Cheese imports from the EEC increased from 8,074 tonnes in 1981-82 to 10,066 tonnes in 1982-83 and from all sources from 16,832 tonnes in 1981-82 to 19,741 tonnes in 1982-83. As the new arrangement with the EEC only came into force in November 1983 it is too early for its impact to be indicated by official import statistics, bearing in mind that some EEC fixations at the old restitution rate apply until April 1984.

(5) In respect of the Downs Co-operative Dairy Association, Toowoomba, Queensland, I understand that the company ceased manufacture of blue vein cheese for some 10 months but production recommenced in November 1983.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Defence

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been a general expansion and upgrading of the equal employment opportunities programs within my Department since the 1983 general election. The following are responses to specific aspects of this question:
(a) Nil.
(b) Equal employment opportunities criteria have been incorporated in departmental instructions and procedures for staff selection and development.

(c) A departmental equal employment opportunity management plan has been developed and adopted, and is being implemented. This plan details the Department's equal employment opportunities program and measures to ensure implementation of the program.
(d) The Department's equal employment opportunities plan includes arrangements for staff and staff association involvement and consultation.

(e) There has been increased consultation with the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau as a widening range of equal employment opportunities initiatives and programs have been implemented.

(f) The Department has upgraded its efforts in the implementation of equal employment opportunities objectives through the introduction of the departmental equal employment opportunities plan and associated programs. The equal employment opportunities program is considered to be an important and integral part of departmental personnel management.
(2) The costs of the Department's equal employment opportunities programs have not been separately identified as the programs are being staffed and funded from within existing resource allocations.
